results.description:
Please join us for a special event on immigration policy for Canadians living in the US. Attorneys from the law firm of Clark Lau LLC, will give a detailed presentation on immigration policy and will take questions after their presentation. Light refreshments will be provided. Only those that have RSVP'd with their full name will be allowed in by security.

The U.S. immigration system is a complex one. Some require sponsorship from an employer while others can be sought independently. Come listen to immigration attorneys from the Clark Lau LLC team who have spoken nationally on the range of topics, including the following:

• Special Treatment for Canadians
• Truth and Myths about the H-1B Visa
• Options for Entrepreneurs and Self-Employment
• Working with Your Employer towards Permanent Residency
• Developing a Portfolio of Extraordinary Ability Speakers:

Steven A. Clark, Founding Partner, Clark Lau LLC

Steve has been the “go to guy” on business immigration for several decades. As national president of the 14,000 member bar association of immigration lawyers (AILA) he successfully advocated for the law which provided 60,000 additional H-1B visas per year and allows certain applicants for permanent residence to extend their H visa beyond the normal 6 year limit. He authored over 100 publications on immigration topics, including employment-based petitions, PERM, H, O, and L visas, and edited many as well. He was editor of the chapter on Labor Certification in the treatise Immigration Law and Practice (Lexis/Nexis) and has been listed as one of “The Best Lawyers in America” under the immigration heading since its inception over two decades ago and is rated “AV,” the highest rating conferred by Martindale-Hubbell, an authoritative, independent rating service. 

Vincent W. Lau, Managing Partner, Clark Lau LLC

Vince counsels employers and employees on a range of temporary and permanent immigration options. His clients include professionals, employers, investors, institutions, entrepreneurs, and families. Vince enjoys taking complex immigration concepts and breaking them down into tangible and comprehensible ideas. It is with this same spirit that he speaks regularly at immigration conferences across the country and has developed a business immigration law curriculum for New England Law Boston. Vince has been named among "The Best Lawyers in America" since 2010. He is a member of AILA’s Department of Labor Liaison Committee for the third year in a row. Most importantly, he has spent his childhood summers in Canada.


Clark Lau LLC is located in the center of Kendall Square in Cambridge at 1 Main Street.

Disclaimer: Please note that the comments made by the speakers are theirs alone and do not necessarily reflect the views of the Consulate General of Canada.
results.name: Navigating through Complex Immigration Waters

group.name: The Boston Expat Canadian Meetup Group

results.description:
SoJust is 9! That's right, it's been NINE years since our first event. Join us to celebrate 9 years, 2700 members, 200 events and countless connections made since 2006. Haven't been to a Socializing for Justice event? It’s time to meet 100+ friendly SoJusters!


Meet like-minded progressives and get connected to great social justice organizations in Boston. SoJust is all about building a cross-issue progressive community and network in Boston. We're doing it by putting the social back in social justice. We focus on creating welcoming spaces that foster relationship-building across issue silos. Join us if you are ready to go beyond allies and build a cross-issue progressive movement.

Cost: $5-$20 collected at the door. Donate $10 or more to enter a door raffle. Raffle entrants also choose which local organization receives 25% of proceeds.

A great spread of complimentary appetizers and cupcakes will be provided.

THIS IS NOT A MEETING
 No Program. No Speaker. Just Us. For Justice.

As always, we'll help you meet people - so no worries if you're new to SoJust. Plus, we'll have "I'm Looking For" and "Ask Me About" tags, a Catalyst Corner staffed by our amazing STARZ (regular attendees), our wildly popular Jobs Board, and Action Stations to make it even more likely you'll find the right connections.

Want to cross-promote your events and campaigns? Looking for like-minded progressives to hang out with in Boston? Are you new to the area and looking for groups to get involved in? Psyched about building strong cross-issue coalitions? Join us!

Yes, we mean you. Members are all ages, races, genders, sexual orientations, levels of activism and professions. Some just moved to Boston and others were born here. We hope you see someone like yourself and meet someone you otherwise wouldn't have.

Hey Organizers! If you're involved with a group or project and want to spread the word, bring flyers for the free lit table. Action Stations - if you have an action that can be done in 2 minutes (sign a petition) or within 2 weeks of the event (attend rally, stuff mass mailing) bring it so SoJusters can get connected to you and your work. This is not a typical tabling event - there will be lots of opportunity to schmooze and network! Email robbie AT robbiesamuels DOT com for more information about the Action Stations.

Job Seekers and Hiring Managers: Mark McCurdy, The NonProfit Career Coach will review your nonprofit resume for free at the event. Meet Mark at the Jobs Board. Looking? Bring your resume! Hiring? Bring your job posting!


ACCESSIBILITY: Must be 21+ to enter after 7PM. The venue is physically accessible - elevator is in the back of the room, accessible restroom is located on a different floor and we've been told are big enough for manual, but not motor-powered, wheelchairs.

PARKING: Lir is across from the Hynes Convention Center. Parking near Lir can be difficult - you could get lucky or you could drive around for 30 or more minutes. There are parking garages by Back Bay station and Sheraton hotel. Best bet is to take the T to Back Bay or Hynes Convention Center (which is the closest T stop).

HELP SPREAD THE WORD!
Invite your friends to the [coming soon].
Join the SoJust Facebook group: http://on.fb.me/SoJust
On Twitter? Follow @SoJust and SoJust's Co-Founder @RobbieSamuels and tweet about this event using #sojust

 

SOCIALIZING FOR JUSTICE - www.sojust.org
SoJust is not a non-profit 501(c)(3). We're a grassroots volunteer-run member-supported cross-issue progressive community that's been growing steadily since August 2006. We have 2500 members, hosted 185 events and manage an online hub of progressive events and resources at www.sojust.org. If you've benefited from this cross-issue progressive network, please contribute the suggested annual membership fee of $25. You may do this online or at any of our events. Thank you for helping us continue to provide a space for like-minded progressives of all stripes.

results.description:
Verizon Cloud Hackathon Boston- a contest to pitch, program, and present a functioning web application.

General Guidelines :
1) The Hackathon is open for all.
2) Team registrations will take place on the evening of July 31st at 6pm. Maximum allowed team size is: 3 people
3) All code, design, and assets must be created during the duration of the Hackathon. 

Ways to Win:

There are multiple ways to win awards at our hackathon -- you can build an app from scratch that compliments Verizon's infrastructure and technologies and win a $500 Gift Card from Verizon Wireless.  The Gift Card can be used online or in any Verizon Wireless Store to purchase incredible technologies including tablets and smart phones.  -- or you can build the best add-on, Tool, or API to the Verizon Cloud and qualify for a development contract with the Verizon Cloud Team! Additional prizes will be presented by our Co-Sponsors.

results.description:
Join BeVisible Boston for our monthly meet up on Thursday, Sept. 17th at Rosa Mexicano! We'll be featuring, Judith Garcia, a powerhouse Latina from Chelsea, MA who is running for City Council. Judith will be sharing with us her story of the life transforming mentoring program she participated in high school, Summer Search. Summer Search tested Judith's ability to overcome major personal obstacles and persevere, lessons that have served her well!

Judith attended Wheaton College, has lived in South Africa and the Middle East, and now works as a HelpLine Counselor at Health Care For All. 

Judith's story is an inspiration to us all, as she has taken her education and life experiences, and is now investing in her community in Chelsea!

We hope that you will support Judith with your presence and encouragement. You are welcome also to donate to her campaign, however that is not required for attendance. Rallying around her is the most important! 

Questions, contact [masked]

Looking forward to seeing you there!
results.name: BeVisible Boston with guest Judith Garcia

UPDATE: Please come out and support your local restaurants! As an incentive to attend and play any Member who signs up to play 50 Seasons of Red Sox Trivia for the FIRST TIME will start out with 5 points. A team of 2 new players could start out with a 10 point lead! Let's give the repeat winners a challenge this week. Trivia begins at 7:15pm. 

Trivia questions will feature a lot of Red Sox Player Nick Names, Trades & Current Events. This is Individual or Group Trivia with Teams of 2 people. You do not need to play in order to attend. For any of you first timers, we actually kind of give you the answers to the questions before we start!

"50 SEASONS of RED SOX TRIVIA" is an EXCLUSIVE EVENT produced by the Red Sox Natives.

Do you know your Red Sox Baseball from the past 50 years? Do you want to compete to win a $50.00 Gift Card to Laurie's 909 or maybe a pair of Red Sox Tickets?

Please join the Red Sox Natives for "50 Seasons of Red Sox Trivia" - The Nick Name/Trade & Current Events Edition at Laurie's 909 on Thursday, September 17. We are looking for a few good Red Sox fans to challenge prior winners from the Natives, Wakefield Weeknights and Laurie's 909 regulars. Individual or Group Trivia with teams of 2 people!

This Event is sponsored by Red Sox Natives Sponsor Laurie's 909 and Red Sox Native Bob from Laurie's along with Dan Pranka from New England Sports Tours. 

Here is the Lineup for the evening:

1. Arrive after work or 6:00pm

2. Enjoy cocktails, appetizers, and dinner with other Red Sox Natives and fans. 

3. Talk Baseball with the Red Sox Natives and other Red Sox fans.

4. Register between 6:00pm and 7:00pm to play 50 Seasons of Red Sox Trivia

5. Red Sox Trivia Begins between 7:00pm and 7:15pm.

6. Individual or Group Teams of 2 people answer approximately 75 questions from Seasons 1965 thru 2015. There will be questions from these seasons and the decades.

7. Individual or Groups with most correct answers and points wins a $50.00 Laurie's 909 Gift Card or maybe a pair of Red Sox tickets. The 2nd and 3rd place individuals win a Gift Card for a free appetizer from Laurie's 909.

 8. Approximately 1.5 to 2 Hour duration.

 9. Take the 909  train back to Boston if you are attending from the City. 

We will be gathering at the "Nickel" Bar at Laurie's.

There is no cover or trivia entry fee.

Full menu is available until 9:30pm. Late night menu is available afterward. If you have a group of people that want a table reservation for dinner please call Laurie's at[masked] and make a reservation. For information on Laurie's 909 and the menu go to www.lauries909.com. .

If this will be your first time meeting the Red Sox Natives Crew please check out the photos of those who RSVP Yes so you can find the group.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. However, if you sit at a group table a group bill may be provided so please communicate with your server when ordering. Credit Cards may be held by the servers at Laurie's.

Laurie's 909 is Wakefield's newest restaurant and Bar with live entertainment several nights per week and many special E Mail list promotions. Laurie's is located at the Wakefield Commuter Rail Train Station in Wakefield. The Reading and Haverhill Commuter Rail trains stop at Laurie's. Laurie's is easily accessible within 10 minutes from Routes 128, 93, 28 and 1. Free parking is available in two lots on Tuttle Street, in the Church parking lot if there are no activities there, and on street after 5:30pm. Check out the MBTA or Hop Stop for additional public transit options including the less reliable/frequent 136 and 137 bus lines.

Check out the "Penny Lane" and "Nickel" Bars, the 9:09 and Beatles references.

More information at http://www.lauries909.com

See you there!

results.description:
We plan to dig into the question of building enterprise sales teams with our special guest speaker who was the first enterprise sales person ever hired by Marc Benioff at Salesforce. He will share his story about how he developed the sales process in the early days at Salesforce and successfully refined that process across three other early stage startup companies.

You will learn the nuts and bolts of what it takes to turn a process built for one into a sales process for an entire sales team that can consistently bag 7 figure deals.  There will be plenty of lessons learned on molding sales operations from a chaotic sprint to a polished, metrics driven sales machine from how to hire and onboard to how to plan and measure towards sales targets.

We will have light refreshments and drinks, an engaging discussion, and a great group of enterprise sales professionals from Boston to celebrate the launch of our Boston community.  We look forward to seeing you then!

Tweet us using #BOSSales @Enterprise_Sale

Sponsors

WeWork is a community for creators. We transform buildings into beautiful, collaborative workspaces and provide infrastructure, services, events and technology so our members can focus on doing what they love. We currently have 43 locations in sixteen cities with over 25,000 members. Book a tour at www.wework.com.

Spiro is the personal sales app for quota-carrying salespeople who want to make more money.  You can sign up for their private beta now at spirohq.com.
results.name: Building the Enterprise Sales Team

results.description:
* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * *
Note: Don't be misled by the title. This lecture is by a scholar of Islam, and concerns competing conceptions of Muhammad; it isn't a lecture with the purpose of challenging Muhammad or Islam. Given the interest so many of our members express, in religion, religiosity, and the nature of belief, we thought it likely some folks here would be interested in attending this lecture, which is free and open to the public. - the BA organizers.
* * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * * The Annual Gerald and Deanne Gitner Family College of Arts & Sciences Lecture: "Contesting Muhammad: Contemporary Controversies in Historical Perspective", presented by Kecia Ali, Associate Professor of Religion.

With respondents Stephen Prothero (Professor of Religion, author of "Religious Literacy: What Every American Needs to Know -- And Doesn't") and Teena Purohit (Assistant Professor of Religion, author of "The Aga Khan Case: Religion and Identity in Colonial India".

About the lecturer: Kecia Ali (Ph.D., Religion, Duke University) teaches a range of classes on Islam. Her research focuses on Islamic law; women and gender; ethics; and biography. Her books include Sexual Ethics and Islam: Feminist Reflections on Qur’an, Hadith, and Jurisprudence (2006), Marriage and Slavery in Early Islam (2010), Imam Shafi‘i: Scholar and Saint (2011), and The Lives of Muhammad (2014), about modern Muslim and non-Muslim biographies of Islam’s prophet. She has also co-edited the revised edition of A Guide for Women in Religion, which provides guidance for careers in religious studies and theology (2014). Ali is active in the American Academy of Religion and currently serves as President of the Society for the Study of Muslim Ethics.
results.name: Lecture: "Contesting Muhammad"

PLEASE NOTE: This event is not run by the Meetup. It's a separate event, being held by the Umbrella Center for the Arts. Tickets are $10.

As BIG Art; Tiny House progresses on the front lawn, the excitement about tiny houses in Concord has been growing.  On Thursday, September 17 at 6:00 hear three local tiny house builders discuss their homes and what they learned while they built them.  Come prepared to learn about the building process, the sustainable side effects of tiny living, and the value of surrounding yourself with handmade objects. Stop by The Umbrella's front lawn before the talk to see our two tiny houses for yourself!

Panel Members:

Daniel Gainsboro, Founder of NOW Communities, Concord, MA and Concord Riverwalk


Miranda Aisling Hynes, Studio Arts Coordinator at The Umbrella, Lead Artist on BIG ART; Tiny House, and Founder of Miranda's Hearth

Tracey Powell, Assoc. AIA, CSI, Architect behind Lil'Lodge to be displayed at ABX 2015 on November 17-19, 2015

Christopher Page, local tiny house builder and expert from Andover, MA

More information here: http://theumbrellaarts.org/event/arttalk-tiny-house-panel

Come dragon boat with Living Root! We're a co-ed team and we're always looking for new paddlers to join us. This is a great way to get in shape, meet people, and do something fun and competitive.  We meet at 6pm at the docks behind the Barking Crab (88 Sleeper Street in Boston), a short walk from South Station.  We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather.  Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you dont mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings.  We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice, and you're welcome to join us.  Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked]. 

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

Check out our website or find us on Facebook!

results.description:
We gather every month for engaging presentations, lively discussions and food/beer! This group gives security researchers in the Greater Boston community the chance to interact with each other more frequently. Each event features three speakers to talk about something a good hacker finds interesting along with discussions about security processes, techniques and much more!

1.  The Quest for User-Friendly Crypto (7:35-7:55) 

by Max Krohn | LinkedIn | Twitter | Keybase

Few technologies in computer science are more theoretically revolutionary than public key cryptography, but as public key nears its 40th anniversary, we've seen remarkably little penetration. Better crypto for everyone is a genuinely hard problem, and we'll discuss what a solution looks like. In particular, we need simultaneous answers to (1) identity lookup; (2) secret key management; and (3) usable, polished applications that hide complexity. At the same time we need to ignore distractions that are noble but not central to the quest. 

About Max. Max Krohn (Founder and CTO of Keybase.io) was the CTO and co-founder of OkCupid.com and SparkNotes.com. He earned a Ph.D. in computer science from MIT in 2008 with a focus on operating systems and security. Most recently, he cofounded Keybase.io, a new company that makes cryptography more practical through better UX and workable key distribution. 


2. From you to Obama: The U.S. Cyber Incident Response Escalation Process (6:45-7:05) 

By Quinn Shamblin | LinkedIn | CSO Magazine Blog | Twitter

In the U.S., we have an official process for escalating cybersecurity incidents from a single organization up through the various levels of an industry’s own Information Sharing and Analysis Center (ISAC), through the National Cybersecurity & Communications Integration Center (NCCIC)—part of the DHS—then through both that industry’s regulation and control groups and, if necessary, up the various levels of National response and policy until—if it is severe enough—it lands in the Situation Room of the White House, in front of the Principles Committee and the President himself. Thus, it is possible that response to a cyber-attack can potentially include kinetic options.  Understanding this process can help you understand how you and your organization might best integrate with it, to take advantages of the resources available to you and understand when it is appropriate to ask for the next level of attention. This presentation is an overview of the process documented in the DHS National Cyber Incident Response Plan (NCIRP). We will also talk about a few fun and interesting cyber attacks from the past few years.

About Quinn. Quinn Shamblin (Executive Director of Information Security at Boston University) has worked in a wide variety of roles and industries: an officer in the Navy; an IT manager at Procter & Gamble; a Project and Relationship Manager for HP; a business process automation consultant for Hydus International; and the cyber-crime investigator, an adjunct professor in the School of Business, and the Director of Information Security for the University of Cincinnati. Quinn leverages that diversity of experience to inform the design and strategy of the Information Security program at Boston University. Quinn is a sought-after presenter in the information security field.  He has given talks for CSO magazine, the Brazilian government, the FBI, Evanta, EDUCAUSE, and many other national, regional, and local organizations.

Quinn holds an MBA from the University of Cincinnati, a B.S. in Physics from Andrews University, and numerous professional certifications, including CISM, CISSP, ITIL and previously, PMP, GIAC Certified Forensics Analyst (GCFA).

3.  Autopsy: Open Source Digital Forensics (7:10-7:30)  

by Brian Carrier | LinkedIn | Twitter

Autopsy is an open source, end-to-end digital forensics platform. It’s Windows-based, easy to use, and has all of the standard digital investigation features (file recovery, keyword searching, hash matching, registry analysis, etc.). Plus, it was built to be a platform and has several frameworks in it for plug-in modules. This talk covers the features of the tool and its plug-in design so that you can try Autopsy as part of your cyber investigations or use it as a development platform. This talk also covers some new image and video analysis functionality that is being provided especially for law enforcement from U.S. Department of Homeland Security funding. Autopsy was first released more than 13 years ago and has thousands of users around the world.

About Brian. Brian (VP of Digital Forensics at Basis Technology) leads the digital forensics team at Basis Technology, delivering commercial incident response software, custom systems, and operational services. He is the author of the book File System Forensic Analysis and developer of several open source digital forensics analysis tools, including The Sleuth Kit and Autopsy. Brian has a Ph.D. in computer science from Purdue University and worked previously for @stake as a research scientist and the technical lead for their digital forensics lab. Brian is on the committees of many conferences, workshops, and technical working groups, including Open Source Digital Forensics Conference (OSDFCon), Digital Forensics Research Conference (DFRWS), and Digital Investigation Journal.


Schedule

6:00 - 6:30: Pizza

6:30 - 6:35: Cybersecurity Opener by Dawn

6:35 - 6:40: Lulzy News by Cindy

6:40 - 6:45: Tool of the month by Will 

6:45 - 7:05:  From you to Obama: The U.S. Cyber Incident Response Escalation Process by Quinn Shamblin 

7:10 - 7:30:  Autopsy: Open Source Digital Forensics by Brian Carrier

7:35 - 7:55:  The Quest for User-Friendly Crypto by Maxwell Krohn

8:00 - 9:00:  Catalyst!

Network with other security enthusiasts!

Physical Security
We'd like to make things easy for Google Security. Everybody should update their meetup profile with their last name and a recent photograph. To do that, click My Profile > View Profile and you'll see the options.

Parking
You may want to allow extra time to find a parking space, but street parking is available on the side streets. Pilgrim Parking, 350 Kendall Street has an $8 rate if you enter after 4pm. 

Not receiving emails?
Some members have said they're not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose Boston Security Meetup under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Why are you charging $1? 
It takes an extraordinary amount of effort and time to put on these events. The nominal $1 fee and checkout process serve to verify your attendance and provide a more accurate headcount — and ensure a much better networking experience! Your modest support does enable and encourage us to continue improving these events.

Sales and Recruiters
We appreciate your interest in our events; however, in order to keep the focus on learning and having fun in a casual environment, we request that you not engage in marketing, sales, or recruitment business at our meetups. If you would like to mingle with our members in a professional capacity to promote a product or recruit, please contact us through the Meetup Messenger about sponsorship opportunities.

Looking for speakers! 
If you sent us an abstract of your talk and haven't received a response yet, please send it again. Your message may have been buried in layers of emails. Reminders are helpful!

results.description:
6:00-7:00 Networking, Introductions, Pizza

7:00-7:45 The Perfect Layering Solution for vCloud Air

Description:  
FSLogix Apps eliminates multiple layers of management infrastructure, creating a single, unified approach to image management, profile access, and application provisioning.  This new, award winning approach can decrease user logon time by > 85%, dramatically reduce server and network overhead, with no sequencing, repackaging, or monolithic, proprietary approach.  See a live demonstration, and learn how Profile Containers, Unified Base Images, and Image Masking are revolutionizing persistent and non-persistent cloud based desktops.

Presenter: Jarian Gibson 
Jarian Gibson is an independent consultant/solutions architect focused on application/desktop virtualization and enterprise mobility technologies based out of the Kansas City area. With more than 15 years of experience in the IT industry, Jarian has worked on many assessment, design, and implementations projects for application/desktop virtualization solutions. Jarian has and maintains industry certifications from Citrix, Microsoft, and VMware to name a few.  Jarian is an active contributor in the Citrix Support Forums, the Citrix IRC channel, and has his own website.  Jarian has presented at conferences (BriForum, Citrix Synergy, and E2E Virtualization Conference), been named Citrix Geek of the Week, recognized by Citrix as one of the top five Citrix engineers in the central region at Citrix Synergy 2011, and contributed to Desktop Virtualization Deployment Insights eBook published by Citrix.

8:00-8:45 Disruptive Innovations in Enterprise Storage

Scott Davis, CTO Infinio 
http://www.infinio.com/

Abstract: A new wave of disruptive innovations in the storage industry is shaking up familiar architectures and technologies. These innovations promise to deliver drive down performance and capacity costs, simplify storage in the data center and challenge the long-established vendors and architectures. Hybrid Arrays are the new normal while All-Flash Arrays and Hyper-Converged Infrastructure solutions are serious contenders in the appropriate use cases.  This session will also cover the emergence of decoupled architectures that separate the delivery of storage performance from storage capacity with unique technologies optimized for each instead of the traditional integrated storage appliances of yesterday. Speaker Scott Davis is uniquely qualified to cover this topic as former VMware CTO of both end user computing and storage, and current industry blogger and CTO at Infinio.  

This session will cover disruptive storage technologies and the solutions they are driving. Attendees will learn about: 
    •          Storage Performance technology innovations such as PCI-e and DIMM-based Flash/SSD 
    •          Storage Capacity technology innovations such as SMR (shingled) drives 
    •          Object and cloud storage trends 
    •          Storage product architectures such as all-flash and hybrid arrays, hyper-converged infrastructure and software-defined storage 
    •          Decoupled (capacity and performance) I/O optimization technologies 
Leave this session understanding more about the architectures and tradeoffs of the next wave of storage technologies. 

Speaker Bio: Scott Davis is Chief Technology Officer at Infinio, a venture-backed storage startup company where he drives product and technology strategy and was formerly CTO of VMware’s End User Computing Business Unit. He was instrumental in driving product and technology strategy spanning the breadth of VMware’s product lines and also served as VMware’s Chief Data Center/Storage Architect and Field CTO. A recognized expert in virtualization, clustering, operating systems, file systems, storage, and end-user computing technologies such as VDI, graphics protocols and mobility/EMM, Mr. Davis has held senior engineering and business management roles with both startup ventures and established industry firms. Prior to joining VMware, he was President, CTO and Founder of Virtual Iron Software, which was acquired by Oracle and became the core of OracleVM. Previously, he was CTO at Mangosoft, an Internet software and storage company with pioneering peer-to-peer clustering, caching and file system products.  Scott began his career at Digital Equipment Corporation where he was Technical Director for the industry-acclaimed VAXCluster and VMS Volume Shadowing products, as well as DEC’s Windows NT clustering technology (later sold to Microsoft as the genesis of Microsoft ‘Wolfpack’ Cluster Server). Scott holds 17 US patents for clustering, storage and virtualization technologies and his products have won awards at Comdex, Demo and LinuxWorld. 

- See more at: http://www.infinio.com/what-we-do#sthash.aB9Bvhlv.dpuf

 8:45- Cleanup and prizes
results.name: Layering Solutions for vCloud Air & Disruptive Innovations in Enterprise Storage

NEXT LEVEL BUSINESS FORUM brings together business-owners, -coaches, and -service-providers, for enlightened discussions. Each participant, expert in his own field, benefits from the others’ perspectives.

This WEEK Business owners and experts will break into various topic groups for round robin sharing of ideas.


Our Expert:

Joe Ryan: Career & Business Coach, Training, Organization & Workforce Development

and others...


See more details in the agenda below.


--

GETTING HERE

Join us at MIT's Cambridge Innovation Center, 1 Broadway, Cambridge, 5th floor, Cozumel Room

• Register as a guest at the front desk and mention that you're attending our event on the 5th floor.

• Optionally: Meet us at Venture Cafe for networking before the event. Venture Cafe serves as a physical nexus for helping innovators and entrepreneurs find one another and collaborate to bring their dreams to reality.  All attendees to the Cafe should adhere to the Venture Cafe contributor model (http://vencaf.org/thursdaycafeboston/contributor-model/) and credo (http://vencaf.org/credo/). Learn more here: vencaf.org.

Follow signs to the Cozumel Room on the 5th floor.

--

GAIN STREET

We're a funded startup at MIT's Cambridge Innovation Center, and we're building an app that's also a "business coach"

- And discover opportunities to take your business to the next level

results.description:
Couch to 5K Fall Group
Interested in getting in shape but don’t know where to begin? Want to meet s

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

Yarnstormers, join in The Caring Forest, a new project to promote the work of Somerville Homeless Coalition and our annual fundraiser, Wrap Around. Sandy McDonald, Jennifer Fuchel and Alice Sajdera will transform Powder House Park in Somervillle later this month. 

We are still looking for knit or crocheted donations. Inspired by mosaic, The Caring Forest is based on the construction of the pieces on multiples of 4” (4”x4”; 4”x8”; 8”x16”; etc). We need squares and rectangles of all kinds: plain and elaborate. Acrylic yarn is the best material.
Details: http://navegallery.org/wp/the-caring-forest/

If you've been working away, come on by to drop off your goodies. Or, come on by to learn more about The Caring Forest and Wrap Around.

Contributions received by September 17 will be assembled for installation on September 26.  Contributions received later will be added to the installation when we can.

results.description:
The Boston Traders Meetup will be hosting a monthly options meeting to discuss options trading. This will be an informal gathering of folks who trade options who would like to share their knowledge and learn from each other. 


Beginners and experienced traders are welcome.


This event will be held on the Thursday evening before the monthly expiration Friday.* Holding the meeting at monthly expiration will allow people to discuss the trades that they have put on during the prior month and perhaps to share ideas for trades to put on in the next month. For weekly options traders, the monthly expiry is of little significance unto itself, but for the monthly options traders, it will hold more significance.

Mary-Lou Drozek will be moderating this meeting. She has been trading options for about 5 years and is happy to share ideas.

The meeting location is Panera Bread in Quincy, which has wifi and is visible from the North Quincy T stop on the Red Line. The location could possibly change, so please check back with the event page just to confirm the location before heading off to the meeting.

-------------------------------------------


* Meetup allows for scheduling "the third Thursday of the month," but not the "Thursday before the third Friday of the month," which is what we need. Using the Meetup scheduling system alone without intervention would mean that the third Thursday will be on expiration week except for those months starting on a Friday, as is the case in August of 2014; in which case, the meeting would fall a week after the monthly expiry week. We believe that we will be able to successfully manipulate this consideration in the meetup system to keep the meetings all on the Thursday evening before expiration Friday. If you see a meeting time that isn't the Thursday evening before expiration Friday, please let us know and we will correct it. Thank you.

Engineering for Connected Patients in the IoT Era

Join us for a night of big data and big ideas at MongoDB Evenings Boston. Learn how to use MongoDB and how to take advantage of the new features in version 3.0. 


MongoDB Solution Architects, experts in the database and its operations, will be your guides for the evening. They'll get you up to speed on MongoDB and will share best practices for developing with and operating the database. 

An added bonus – learn about new storage engine capabilities in Wired Tiger.

Enjoy beer and pizza, and the company of MongoDB Engineers who will answer all your questions. 

**Space is limited. Register now to claim your seat!**

What to expect
• Walk away with immediately applicable skills 
• Learn new techniques for scaling your infrastructure 
• Network with MongoDB engineers and fellow technologists in your local community

Agenda
6:00pm: Pizza & Soft Drinks
6:30pm: Reducing Development Time with MongoDB vs. SQL, presented by Buzz Moschetti, Enterprise Architect, MongoDB
7:00pm: A Technical Introduction to WiredTiger, presented by Keith Bostic, Senior Staff Engineer, Storage Engine, MongoDB
7:30pm: Engineering for Connected Patients in the IoT Era, presented by Anurag Singhal, Director of Engineering, Clinical Ink
8:00pm: Q&A with MongoDB Experts

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

The French Cultural Center is hosting a free ($5.00 donation suggestion) French film, Venus in Fur (2013)"La Vénus à la Fourrure".

Even though this is a free event, a reservation is required.


You may register online at 

http://events.constantcontact.com/register/event?llr=em45fybab&oeidk=a07ebeemv6x990e5906

or via phone at[masked]-0400.


This is a relatively small venue which seats approximately 70 people.  Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

The film starts at 6:30pm, however the meeting time for this event is set for 6:00 pm in the reading room.  The film will be presented in the adjacent room, the ballroom.  The plan is to gather and meet-up in the reading room and then go to the film viewing room at 6:30 pm.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

** *

Film Information - 


French drama, La Vénus à la fourrure, directed by Roman Polanski in 2013.


To view the trailer, http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2406252/ 

Adapted from the play by David Ives (which played at the Huntington Theater in January 2014), this fascinating film tells the story of an actress (Emmanuelle Seigner) attempting to convince a director (Mathieu Amalric) that she's perfect for a role in his upcoming production. As her audition progresses, the director--and the audience--must confront questions of obsession, identity, power and even reality. Roman Polanski won the César for Best Director for this film in 2014. 


This 2013, 95-minute film will be presented in its original version, with English subtitles.

The screening will conclude with an open discussion led by our in-house film expert, Barbara Bouquegneau.

Directions and Parking Information


• Getting here via public transportation (MBTA)Green Line

Get off at Arlington station. Walk north along Arlington Street toward the Charles River. Turn left onto the third street, Marlborough Street. The Center is at the end of the block, at the opposite corner on the right.

Via the Orange Line or Commuter Rail

Get off either train at Back Bay Station. Walk north along Clarendon Street toward the Charles River. Turn right onto the fifth street, Marlborough Street. The Center is at the end of the block, on the left corner.

• Parking

Parking is available at the Boston Common Parking Garage (located at Zero Charles St, below the Boston Common Park) on Saturdays all day and on week days after 4pm for $10. Buy your discounted ticket with our receptionist.

http://www.frenchculturalcenter.org/index.cfm/about-us/directions-hours/

results.name: Venus is Fur (2013) "La Vénus à la Fourrure"- French Film Screening - Free

results.description:
This will be the first of a new Current Events meetup series. We aim to have reoccurring sessions moving forward so we can stay abreast of these issues both as individuals and together as a community. We have seen a huge surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, politicians and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Have a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting that isn't listed below? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share a current event you've learned about over the past month or so. If not, feel free to come and listen, learn, and participate in some really important discussions. Looking forward to seeing you all there and kicking off this new series! September Current Events:

- Confederate Flags
- Police Brutality and Body Cameras in Boston
- WEDBJ Shooting
- Trump's Blatant Racism
- BLM interrupting political speeches
results.name: Current Events: Anti-Racism and What's Happening Now

results.description:
Summer's coming!  Let's add a night of cocktails and conversation at the waterfront for those hot summer nights!  You may live in Cambridge, Somerville or Charlestown, but this will give you an excuse to get out of your local neighborhood and head downtown!  

Join the New England Network for Women starting in May for a relaxed night of cocktails and conversation every third Thursday of the month at the InterContinental Boston Hotel on the waterfront.  Please come prepared to mingle with a fabulous group of empowering women who will share stories and tips on their business ventures! 


Whether you are networking to meet potential new clients, learn new tips and techniques from seasoned businesswomen, share ideas and experiences with open and like-minded women or just to meet new friends in the area, this is the group for you.  Meet at the rear of the hotel closest to the waterfront at the Rumba Rum & Champagne Lounge and bring your marketing materials and business cards to distribute.  If it's warm, we will move outdoors to the fabulous waterfront!  We aim to have a member speaker at each gathering, whom I have listed below.  If you would like to give a presentation at one of our meetings, please scroll down to  see if someone has been selected yet.  If not, you may inquire about being our speaker of the evening.  In order to speak, your membership dues must be current and you may pay your dues online or at your next meeting.  

Happy chatting and best wishes on your endeavors!  

As always, I welcome any questions you may have regarding our group or your business ventures! 

Stacey Mac, Owner
Sonas Ventures LLC, which owns and operates:
Sonas Real Estate, a division of Century 21 Abigail Adams
Sonas Assistants, Workshops on Executive Assistant Training
SUP SONAS, Stand Up Paddleboarding, Surfing & Travel in Boston, New England and Costa Rica

YES - park in the lot

NO - don't cut in line

YES - get there early (doors at 7. get there by 6:45)

YES - dress for stargazing

YES - look for the meetup sign, or just talk to the people around you. Everyone here is Nerdy and Fun whether or not they found out about this event from this meetup group.

We generally sit on the back left of the auditorium. Or we get there too late and end up in the overflow room. THEN we try to find each other in telescope lines on the roof.

MAYBE - we'll go out somewhere after, maybe not. Folks might be tired, or hard to collect into a group, or self-organizing and looking for beer, or burgers.


- H

From the Harvard stop on the MBTA Red Line, take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue in Cambridge (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses; Huron Avenue trolley) and get off at the Observatory Hill stop.

For more information go to  http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/events or call 617.495.7461.


The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

Exploding Stars


Dan Milisavljevic, CfA

Approximately once every second, somewhere in the universe a star ends its life in a catastrophic explosion called a supernova. These cosmic blasts shape and enrich their parent galaxies, produce exotic objects like neutron stars and black holes, and manufacture the heavy elements that make planets like Earth – and its life – possible. Dan Milisavljevic will explore cutting-edge research that is unraveling the many mysteries of supernova explosions, and highlight recent breakthroughs in our ability to survey supernova debris fields in 3D and diagnose a star's impending doom.


******************************

NOTE: if anyone would like to be an assistant organizer to help run various* events please contact me - Heather

*various = various science and nerdy events around town, and NOT the ones that only market your own event/product.  (SPAM=no)

The waiting list and attendance limit is for the CfA to have a more accurate attendance count.

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

H

results.description:
Ongoing class in 18th century Scottish Broadsword and Smallsword.

The Broadsword is the archetypal weapon of the Highlander swordsman - a broad-bladed cutting and thrusting weapon. It has a basket hilt to protect the hand and wielded single-handed.

The Smallsword is the courtly weapon of the Scottish warrior class. An elegant thrusting weapon it teaches the fighter to use the thrust and make small parries. The smallsword is the immediate predecessor to modern epee.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.

All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Scottish Smallsword & Broadsword

results.description:
Yo yo yo - time to meetup in September!  We have a GREAT double header event this month.


First up,  our event co-sponor HP will present an overview of Ceph storage, using material taken from HP's publicly available OpenStack courses. The focus will be on the basic functionality, building blocks, and configurations that comprise this flexible storage capability frequently used with OpenStack.


Presenters include long time OpenStack supporters Harry Sutton and Bill Horzempa of HP.


Session two brings us John Dickinson: John is Director of Technology with Swiftstack and is the PTL for the OpenStack Swift project.  John will share valuable stuff that's going to make developing with Swift easy by offloading the hard problems of storage. OpenStack Swift makes your application better.  John will cover how application developers can take advantage of some of the more advanced features in Swift, including... TempURL, StaticWeb, FormPost, and Static or Dynamic Large Objects among others.


John will also cover what is coming in OpenStack Swift from a Roadmap perspective.


John joined SwiftStack in 2011 as Director of Technology coming from Rackspace.  As the Project Technical Lead (PTL) for OpenStack Swift, John has been a leading force on Projects such as Geographical Clustering, Storage Policies, and most recently Erasure Codes. John is also leading much of its community development efforts.


Reminders:

• A light dinner and soft drinks will be provided ~ 6:30pm courtesy of HP, and we will kick off the sessions ~ 7:00pm.

• If you are interested in giving a Lightening Talk shoot us a note with a topic or just come to the session ready to speak!

• DON'T FORGET - for security reasons, the NERD center requires attendees to show a government issued photo ID in order to gain access into the building.

• Parking: Best option for parking is the NERD center parking garage which charges a flat rate after 4pm.
results.name: September OpenStack Meetup - Storage Double Header Event!!

results.description:
Cambridge meetup is back! We are going to have this event every other week!


http://www.championscambridge.com/


As usual, please bring your driver's license or passport, if you would like to have alcohol. They are strict about IDs, No IDs no booze.  But people under 21 are welcome as well to this event  - Champions is almost as much a restaurant as a bar and you need not order a drink.


You are responsible for your own consumption and please start and settle your own tab. Please bring your Credit/Debit card or cash and start your tab with the waiter.    Please be sure to tip - we suggest 20% as it is a lot of extra trouble for them to do separate tabs, but it saves us work and allows people to leave at different times.  But first be sure that the tip is not included already - it usually is not but occasionally is, at 18%, if there is a large group, in which case you need not tip additional.  (If you know the price of what you ordered, and add 6.25% MA meals tax, and that is the total, they have NOT added in the tip.)

RSVP required. Please sign up. If you RSVP "Yes," but your plans change, please change your RSVP to "No" so others can sign up. Deadline for reservation is 3PM as we need to get an accurate head count for the reservation. On nights when we are expecting many people, we limit the RSVP number to 27. However, if you'd like to attend, but can't RSVP, send a message to an organizer, as we may be able to get you in.


Champions is located at MIT/Kendall Sq. station. If you come from Boston side, you will see right in front of the T exit. It is part of the Marriott. Even though the address is listed as 50 Broadway, you can really only see it from the Main street side.  We are usually either in the separate room toward the Marriott lobby, or else at two long central tables in the room to the right of the host station.

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Introduction to Aurelia (http://aurelia.io). It is a very interesting new SPA (Single Page Application) javascript framework by Rob Eisenberg and the core Aurelia team.

A key feature of Aurelia is a strong dependence on Javascript ES2015 and ES2016 features with transpiling using BabelJS to ES5.  Overall, the architecture of Aurelia is very clean and straightforward.  With two-way, one-way and one-time binding, custom html element and attribute creation incorporated in a very simple way, and a very modular, plugin-friendly approach, it makes creating websites delightful.  

The presenter is not a core Aurelia team member, but he has been implementing Aurelia applications, one small application is already in production, another one is open source, BEL Mgr and nearing release.  He also has a previous history of AngularJS applications and a variety of server-based web applications.

Presenter:  William Hayes PhD, CTO of Selventa Inc

Aurelia Presentation

Pizza and soda will be provided.

Location: Yieldbot offices Maynard, 1 Clock Tower Place, Suite 330 
Park in the parking lot off of Main St. or in the parking garage. 
Enter the building by the parking garage and up to the 3rd floor.
results.name: Aurelia (SPA framework)

results.description:
{This popular topic has already received great feedback from other Heartbeat Salons, and now Karin and Mark are bringing it to the MetroCharles area...

Shadow Work® - Discover what it is like to live from all of who you are! }

In our Heartbeat Salon this evening...

Karin and Mark, Shadow Work® facilitators, believe that our parents and our culture have encouraged us -- sometimes strongly -- to repress parts of ourselves and to believe and act as they expect. The result is that we may live our lives from a small part of who we really are, and maybe in ways that don’t really feel right.  


Tonight, they will give us an opportunity to work with four archetypal energies, which make up the human psyche: 

• Our Sovereign energy, which makes powerful choices, blesses ourselves and others, and appreciates who we each uniquely are;

• Our Magician energy, which detaches from situations, recognizes persistent patterns, and develops new solutions;

• Our Lover energy, which enables greater intimacy, connection, and creativity;

• Our Warrior energy, which clarifies our identity, helps us set healthy boundaries, and takes powerful action in the world.

To Prepare for the evening, here are some questions to consider:
• What do you want to have happen (in your life)? 
• What persistent, unwanted patterns keep repeating?
• What unwanted thoughts repeat in your mind?
• What characteristics of others really annoy you?
• What (or who) would you like to bring into your life?

Note:    Please wear comfortable, loose clothes. 

Bonus: Download the Shadow Work Basic CD. (It's free and gives an overview of their model.)

OUR LEADERS for this workshop

Mark Massoni is a PGN organizer, a Certified Shadow Work® Group Facilitator, a Shadow Work® trained coach, and a domestic and a sexual assault counselor.  He works with abusive fathers, has facilitated men's groups with the ManKind Project for over 10 years, and is a cabinet and furniture maker.

Karin Green is a Certified Shadow Work Facilitator. Karin is also a transformational life coach, assisting her clients to overcome fears, make positive changes, and create positive impact in their lives. She is a graduate of Priestess Path, Women in Power, and Women Within International. She has facilitated women's groups for 15+ years. www.shadowwidom.com

What people say about this evening...

"Fabulous work -- three experiential exercises that touched all participants deeply. Very well conceived and executed 2 hour presentation that left lecture behind to give us real revelation. Thank you Karin and Mark." ~Dennis

"Deeply emotionally moving. Felt a bit like taking part in an archeological dig... sifting through layers of stored history, unearthing feelings long buried. This is powerful work, ably and lovingly brought forward by Karin & Mark who effortlessly guided us to access inner territory and uncover gifts buried there. I was surprised by how many tears came as a result of taking part in this work. Shadow work feels like it offers the promise of deep healing work to come forth rather effortlessly."  ~Jeff

"This was a surprisingly powerful evening, and we got a delicious taste of the possibility of the Shadow Work. I love doing deep work in a safe environment, and the work we got to do in this evening has already made a difference in my life. Highest recommendation for Mark and Karin. Check it out, people! You'll be glad you did."  ~Lauren E.


Links

Members pay $10 as on Monday night, non-member drop-in is $25.  Membership fee for each month of $25 brings discounts on drawing and painting sessions and classes.  Pay membership fee online (see left-hand column) via paypal or credit card, or in person with cash or check.  First session of the month would therefore be $35 ($25 membership fee plus $10 session fee) and each session thereafter would be $10.

results.description:
Register at: http://ewebinars.com/webinar/?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default&memberid=9778&webid=jlppjxwrep

So You:

a. Just read a real estate investing book
b. Attended your first seminar
c. Watched a late night infomercial
d. Listened to a webinar

And You:

a. Were told real estate is the fastest way to make money
b. Are convinced that you will be able to leave the job that you hate within the next 2 weeks
c. Thought about or have already paid $20,000 for a coaching program

But You:

a. Don't know what to do next
b. Were told by someone that it would never work
c. Are losing your confidence rapidly

Don't be embarrassed. Every person that got into real estate that wasn't hand held by a family member and grew up in the business started out the same way. 90 percent or more of those who have gotten excited about real estate never ended up even trying. Thinking big, attracting money, and being in control of your own destiny sound good, especially when a polished salesperson is the one painting the picture. The reality is: Real Estate is a business and it is hard work. The only people who will tell you otherwise are trying to sell you something(seminar, a coaching program, a book, a subscription). That's the bad news.

The good news is that there are a ton of easy steps that you can take in order to start moving in the right direction without doing anything drastic. And, if you put in the work, the results will come. On this webinar, Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development, will discuss:

1. Why real estate is the toughest industry to get into
2. How it can be the best industry to be in once you have momentum
3. Steps that you can take this week to start your real estate career
4. The basics of wholesaling

5.  Our training program that allows you inside access to our exact marketing programs that you can use to find deals to wholesale

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions for the company. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has helped his team to acquire over 34 properties in the past 6 months including both fix and flip and buy and hold transactions.

To sign up, please go to:

http://ewebinars.com/webinar/?trackingID1=XXXXXXXX&trackingID2=YYYYYYYYY&landingpage=default&expiration=default&memberid=9778&webid=jlppjxwrep<a href="https://attendee.gotowebinar.com/register/5474109221069365505"></a>

results.description:
In this introduction to Integrated Energy Therapy®, you will learn how to create a “heartlink” to the nine Healing Angels of the Energy field.  You will use this link in a guided meditation to connect with and receive a gift from each of the angels.   The heartlink technique that you learn in this workshop can be used any time to connect with any angel.  The link serves as a channel between your heart and the heart of an angel, where you receive energy and information.  Please join us and meet these powerful, loving angels who are so happy to share their gifts with you!

You will also be introduced to the powerful healing modality known as “Integrated Energy Therapy” or “IET” through a brief informational session.  IET works by releasing traumatic imprints or "blocks" from the body’s cellular memory areas and filling the areas with empowering energy.  Cellular memory areas are the places in our energy fields where we store the memories of our feelings - suppressed traumas, emotions, fears, and limiting beliefs.  Releasing these energy blocks allows life force energy to flow freely, resulting in improved health on a physical, mental, emotional and spiritual level.   For each harmful energy imprint that is cleared from the energy field, the cellular memory area is filled with the opposite energy.

$10 fee will be applied toward Basic Level IET Certification training if you decide to enroll.

REGISTRATION:  Please register through Circles of Wisdom by calling[masked] or register online using this link.
results.name: Intro to IET & Healing Angel Meditation

results.description:
TICKETS UPDATE

According to the theater staff, the production company has set a firm window on group rate reservations. This means we need to purchase our ticket block no later than this coming Tuesday. Therefore: if you plan to attend, I need to either have received payment for your tickets or have heard from you directly via email ([masked]) indicating that I should reserve a seat for you and that you are committing to purchasing a ticket. 

If you pay via cash, check, or direct bank transfer to me, your cost is $39/ticket. If you elect to pay through the Meetup site directly, there is an additional processing charge from the WePay system, so your ticket price turns into $45/ticket. To be clear: none of this money goes to your Meetup organizers... it is all for either the ticket price, or payment processing.

I will be placing our group reservation order on Tuesday, July 7th; I will expect to receive hard copy tickets by the beginning of the next week. Anyone who has paid by the end of next week, will receive their ticket from me directly by mail or pick-up (depending on your preference); if you have NOT paid by the end of next week, I shall have to open up your spot in the group reservation to anyone else who wants to go. Those tickets will go to whoever pays next, first come, first serve. 

If after you have your ticket, you learn you're not able to attend, you'd be at your leisure to either see if anyone else in the group (or in Sunday Assembly Boston) wants to buy it from you. 

* * *

Let's enjoy a night of musical theater (and, yes, perhaps a bit of irreverence). Please RSVP if you're certain you (and your guests, should you wish to bring any) will be able to attend. It's important we get a headcount we can rely on sooner rather than later, since the group sales tickets are paid in advance and are non-refundable.


In order to ensure as many members are able to attend as possible, we're trying to keep the cost low, so we've elected to book a block of seats in the balcony -- this ticket rate is $39/seat, plus whatever processing fee is attached. So budget that amount! BA is attending this show with folks from our neighbor group, Sunday Assembly Boston.

Dinner or drinks afterwards, obviously! For more information about the show: http://www.citicenter.org/buy/show-listing/book-of-mormon.
results.name: The Book of Mormon: The Musical

results.description:
Events for the Public

The Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics sponsors a variety of free programs for the public. Among these events are Observatory Nights held on the third Thursday of the month (excluding June, July and August). Observatory Nights feature a nontechnical lecture and telescopic observing from the observatory roof if weather permits. The lectures are intended for high-school age and older audiences but children are also welcome. We also sponsor a variety of other special observing events throughout the year. No reservations are necessary, but seating is limited to the auditorium's capacity. Admission is free.

These events--unless otherwise noted--are held in Phillips Auditorium (at the rear of the CfA complex near Madison Street and large parking lot), 60 Garden Street, Cambridge, about 1 mile west of Harvard Square. Parking lots marked for Observatory Staff are open to the public on event nights. Parking is free.

The Observatory does not host private events.

Monthly Observatory Night
Thursday, September 17, 2015
7:30 pm: Topic TBD

For more information, including accessibility, or to sign up for the events mailing list, call the Public Affairs Office, (617)[masked] or email [masked]. Please request sign-language interpretation at least 2 weeks before the event. Current sky information is available.

Entrance is at the west of the CfA complex, near Madison Street and large parking lot. The CfA is easily reached by public transportation. From the Harvard MBTA Station (Red Line), take any bus or trackless trolley going west on Concord Avenue (Arlmont Village and Belmont Center buses, Huron Avenue trolleys) and get off at "Observatory Hill."

Source(s): http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/publicevents

Also available via their YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ObsNights
results.name: Monthly Observatory Night

results.description:
Couples therapy is a whole new world. What works in individual therapy often makes things worse when there's more than more than one client in the room. Come learn crucial ways in which couples therapy differs, and relational insights you can use to improve your work with individuals.

This is a collaborative meeting between this Meetup group and Lesley University, so there will be a good number of other attendees there, not just the ones who RSVP here.


We'll meet on Thursday, September 17th, in room 3-094 of Lesley University. (Lesley is a secure facility; see below for how to get in and where to  park.) There is no charge for the talk, and all are welcome. Optionally, two Continuing Education credit hours are available to LMHCs for $10.


Please be there by 7:30 pm, when Irle Goldman, a Lesley teacher, will have attendees introduce themselves. Eric Albert, LMHC will present, then we'll open things up for Q&A, followed by an opportunity for people to network. Feel free to bring food. Come join us!

•  Entering from Massachusetts Avenue: There are two entrances. Use the one on the right, closer to Roseland Street and farther from the T stop. Go straight till the Security Desk is on your right. Take the elevator behind the desk to the 3rd floor. The floor map straight ahead on the opposite wall shows the location of 3-094 and rest rooms.

• Entering from back parking lot: Bring your parking receipt with you. Go straight till the Security Desk is on your left. (Get your parking receipt validated here when you leave.) Take the elevator behind the desk to the 3rd floor. The floor map straight ahead on the opposite wall shows the location of 3-094 and rest rooms.

• Parking: Street parking at 2-hour meters is available, but tight. Right behind the Porter Exchange building there is a parking lot, which you enter from Roseland Street. Rates:
    $2 for 2.5 hours or less; $8 for 2.5 - 3.5 hours; $15 for 3.5 - 8 hours;
    half off ($1 / $4 / $8) with a store receipt for $10 or more

• By T: Take the Red Line to Porter Square; The Porter Exchange building (1815 Massachusetts Avenue) is a block away.

• Map showing parking lot and entrances: http://g.co/maps/vg3jk

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: German Longsword

MEET AT THE PLAZA THEATRE BOX OFFICE 30 MINUTES BEFORE CURTAIN.

LA HIJA DE RAPPACCINI


By Daniel Catán

Libretto by Juan Tovar
after Octavio Paz and Nathaniel Hawthorne September 17-19, 8pm

Plaza Theatre at the Boston Center for the Arts
539 Tremont St., Boston, MA 02116

The opera’s libretto presents a complex portrait of the ethics of science and medicine and the tension between progress and humanity. Beatriz is the protégée of her mad scientist father. In developing her talents and protecting her body as a scientific specimen, Dr. Rappaccini has turned her touch to poison. A twist on the classic femme fatale, Beatriz wants to love but her body is riddled with poison from the toxic plants she and her father experiment with. How far will they go to find cures for diseases? What is the distinction between science and medicine? Can one live for both work and love?

OperaHub is a fiscally sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Donations for the purposes of OperaHub must be made payable to Fractured Atlas and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

FREE, ticket required.

http://bit.ly/1JEMRD7

Comedy Central's Mike Vecchione headlines this month's edition of Strange Behavior, a stand-up comedy show hosted by Ryan Donahue at the historic Davis Square Theatre.

Thursday, 9/17 features: 

Mike Vecchione (The Tonight Show, Comedy Central, Inside Amy Schumer)
Rob Haze (NBC's Last Comic Standing)
Noah Savage (New York International Fringe Festival) 

for tix and info: http://bit.ly/1JEMRD7

Mike Vecchione Bio: 

At the end of 2003, Mike moved to New York City. He has appeared on Comedy Centrals Live at Gotham, Comedy Centrals Fresh Face Debates, and Russell Simmons Presents: Stand Up at the El Rey Theatre. Mike also had a guest appearance on the IFC hit show Z Rock. 


In 2010, Mike won the People’s Choice Award for the New York Comedy Festival, was a semi-finalist on NBC’s Last Comic Standing, and was selected to perform at the prestigious Montreal Comedy Festival (New Faces). Later that year, Mike went on to perform on the Tonight Show starring Jay Leno and shot his own Half Hour Special for Comedy Central.
In 2014, Mike appeared on Comedy Underground with Dave Attell on Comedy Central, was again a semi-finalist on NBC’s Last Comic Standing and Comics Unleashed with Byron Allen.
In 2015, Mike appeared on Conan on TBS and Inside Amy Schumer.
Mike headlines across the United States and is based in New York City.

For more information:
www.facebook.com/strangebehaviorcomedy
www.davissquaretheatre.com

results.description:
September 18, 2015

Learn How to Wow Prospects in Under 30 Seconds at the North Shore Business Forum.

“Racing to ‘Wow’ in 27 Seconds: Your Elevator Speech on Fire!”

Tony Toledo, Storyteller

Every business owner has likely experienced that moment when a potential customer asks, “So, what do you do?” You want to supply a short, pithy answer that will leave them in awe, but what comes out of your mouth sounds more like a cross between a belching goose and a lonely cow speaking Russian. Avoid this tragedy by wearing your thinking cap to this NSBF meeting, where Tony will provide examples of great elevator speeches (and examples of stinkers). You’ll take time to think of three ways you help your customers, work in pairs to “interview” others about your business stories, and then try out your brand-new 30-second introduction.

About the Speaker: Tony Toledo has been telling stories in order to eat since 1990, and in fact bought his massive one-tenth-of-an-acre estate with his mouth. The Beverly, MA-based storyteller sells the idea of stories to school principals, who sell the idea of folktales to their teachers, who in turn sell “The Little Rooster and the Turkish Sultan” to their students. Only when everybody is on board can magic happen. According to Tony, “We are all in sales no matter what business we are in. Knowing this is the key to success.” For the past seven years, he hosted the weekly “Speak Up, the Spoken Word Open Mic” in Lynn, MA. Tony is also past president of LANES, the League for the Advancement of New England Storytelling, which recently honored him with the Brother Blue Storytelling Award. For more information, contact Tony at [masked] or visit TonyToledo.com.

The North Shore Business Forum meets on Friday, September 18, 2015 at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. Featured speaker and full-time storyteller Tony Toledo will lead an intensive workshop on how to set your “elevator speech” on fire. Registration begins at 7:15 AM, the meeting runs from 7:30 to 8:30. Admission is $10 at the door, and includes a buffet breakfast. Visit www.nsbforum.org for more information.
results.name: Re-write your Elevator Speech with Tony Toledo

group.name: North Shore Business Forum - Business Networking at Acapulco

results.description:
September 18 - 20 (Fri - Sun)

Enjoy a weekend camping on islands in Casco Bay. We'll launch from Yarmouth, ME on Friday afternoon and paddle out to camp on one of the islands of the Maine Island Trail. Saturday we'll paddle out to Eagle Island to see Admiral Peary's summer house, and then explore other islands, and then return to Yarmouth on Sunday. We'll paddle 6-8 miles per day, spending 3-4 hours on the water. Otherwise we'll explore some of the islands, go swimming or fishing. Cost for launch fees, parking, and trip are expected to be $50 per person.

The start time is approximate. To attend this paddle, you need some experience camping and able to paddle for 3-4 hours. Weather can change during multi-day trips, so we might encounter adverse conditions (wind, waves) and you need to be able to handle this. To register, contact Rob Nardone ([masked]) and please include 2-4 places you have paddled the last few years, including location, distance, and conditions. Once registered, Rob will provide launch details and other needed info.
results.name: Casco Bay Kayak Camping Trip

Big data is one of today’s most exciting sectors, whether you are a software engineer, or a business executive. The BDF big data day will help you expand your knowledge in this growing and innovative field.
