results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
What's Good People?

Check this out below.  Man, I've learned quite a bit about the Moynihan Report over the years, but I expect some real knowledge to be dropped at this discussion.  If you don't know what the Moynihan report is, then I suggest you hit this joint up and have fun learning about it!

I recommend coming 15 mins before 3pm to find a seat.  See the information below!

http://www.harvard.com/event/daniel_geary_and_benjamin_hedin/ 


This event is free and open to the public; no tickets are required!

Harvard Book Store welcomes Professor in U.S. History at Trinity College Dublin DANIEL GEARY and author and essayist BENJAMIN HEDIN for a moderated discussion with The Reverend EUGENE F. RIVERS III of Geary's and Hedin's books Beyond Civil Rights: The Moynihan Report and Its Legacy and In Search of the Movement: The Struggle for Civil Rights Then and Now.

This event is co-sponsored by Boston Review, the Hutchins Center for African and African American Research, and Mass Humanities.

On Beyond Civil Rights: The Moynihan Report and Its Legacy:

Shortly after the 1964 Civil Rights Act, Daniel Patrick Moynihan authored a government report titled The Negro Family: A Case for National Action that captured the attention of President Lyndon Johnson. Responding to the demands of African American activists that the United States go beyond civil rights to secure economic justice, Moynihan thought his analysis of black families highlighted socioeconomic inequality. However, the report's central argument that poor families headed by single mothers inhibited African American progress touched off a heated controversy. The long-running dispute over Moynihan's conclusions changed how Americans talk about race, the family, and poverty.

Fifty years after its publication, the Moynihan Report remains a touchstone in contemporary racial politics, cited by President Barack Obama and Congressman Paul Ryan among others.Beyond Civil Rights offers the definitive history of the Moynihan Report controversy. Focusing on competing interpretations of the report from the mid-1960s to the late 1970s, Geary demonstrates its significance for liberals, conservatives, neoconservatives, civil rights leaders, Black Power activists, and feminists. He also illustrates the pitfalls of discussing racial inequality primarily in terms of family structure. Beyond Civil Rights captures a watershed moment in American history that reveals the roots of current political divisions and the stakes of a public debate that has extended for decades.

On In Search of the Movement: The Struggle for Civil Rights Then and Now:

In March of 1965, Martin Luther King led thousands in an epic march from Selma, Alabama to the state capital in Montgomery, in what is often seen as the culminating moment of the Civil Rights movement. The Voting Rights Act was signed into law that year, and with Jim Crow eradicated, and schools being desegregated, the movement had supposedly come to an end. America would go on to record its story as an historic success.

Recently, however, the New York Times featured an article that described the reversion of Little Rock's schools to all-black or all-white. The next day, the paper printed a story about a small town in Alabama where African Americans were being denied access to the polls. Massive demonstrations in cities across the country protest the killing of black men by police, while we celebrate a series of 50th-anniversary commemorations of the signature events of the Civil Rights movement. In such a time it is important to ask: In the last fifty years, has America progressed on matters of race, or are we stalled--or even moving backward?

With these questions in mind, Benjamin Hedin set out to look for the Civil Rights movement. "I wanted to find the movement in its contemporary guise," he writes, "which also meant answering the critical question of what happened to it after the 1960s." He profiles legendary figures, like John Lewis, Robert Moses, and Julian Bond, and also visits with contemporary leaders such as William Barber II and the staff of the Dream Defenders. But just as powerful--and instructional--are the stories of those whose work goes unrecorded, the organizers and teachers who make all the rest possible.

In these pages the movement is portrayed as never before, as a vibrant tradition of activism that remains in our midst. In Search of the Movement is a fascinating meditation on the patterns of history, as well as an indelible look at the meaning and limits of American freedom.
results.name: Author Discussion:  Beyond Civil Rights: The Moynihan Report and Its Legacy

results.description:
Gather to make fresh, lacto-fermented salsa together

Just a little bit of lacto-fermentation makes fresh salsa taste better right away and then stay fresh for a month or more in your fridge..so maybe you'll be snacking on your favorite homemade salsa made with the freshest summer tomatoes...in late October!! More fun to do all the chopping and jar packing together in a group. What to bring:
Cutting board and knife
Jars (or buy some here)
Fresh cilantro, a bunch or two
Fresh jalapenos or other hot or sweet peppers
Red onions or green onions
Fresh tomatoes (or order organic bulk tomatoes from Picadilly Farm for delivery here:  order by Wednesday night at this link:  [link to Picadilly Tomato order form to come soon], 20 pounds/half bushel of tomatoes for $30.


About 2 pounds of vegetables fit into a quart size canning jar (wide mouth), so estimate about 1.5 pounds of tomatoes needed for each quart of salsa you'd like to take home with you.


I'll provide a scale, bowls, limes, salt, whey (from yogurt), extra jars and lids, a few extra cutting boards.

$5-10 suggested donation to help cover supplies and meetup group costs.
results.name: Lacto-fermented fresh tomato salsa making

results.description:
For New Members AND NON-Members:

For every sailor who walks through our door, start here! This FREE Orientation class will get you familiar with how everything works at CBI. The orientation class is the gateway to everything that CBI has to offer, whether you’re a seasoned sailor or brand new to boats. Done entirely on the dock, your orientation will include a guided tour of CBI’s boats and facilities, an overview of our classes and programs, as well as plenty of time to ask the questions that matter to you as a sailor. All orientations meet at the base of the American Flag Pole out on the dock, and runs for about half an hour. All are welcome to this class!


Afterwards, we invite you to meet one another and ask about other Orientation class attendees' prior experience with sailing. Perhaps you can find a friend to take the Beginner Sailing classes together with once you join. 

Friday Nights are also when CBI members go out for Informal Racing, so it is an exciting night to watch the sailors and learn more about how you can progress your skills after learning to sail. Certainly ask your Orientation instructor about the Friday Night Informal Racing and Informal Instruction if he or she does not mention it. If you have any questions, please feel free to post below!
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.community-boating.org/about-us/hours-and-directions/
results.name: FREE Orientation Class at Community Boating

Join 500 guests at Boston's largest fall singles event! The Museum of Science offers fun, interactive and educational exhibits, from breathtaking dinosaurs to nanotechnology applications. Join us to meet new people and practice English while exploring this fascinating museum! The first 4 MLS students to RSVP will receive free admission!

For more information, visit the MLS website:
http://www.mylanguagesolutions.com/#!museum-of-science-tour/c24y3
results.name: Museum of Science Tour (Friday, September 18, 6:30 - 8:30 P.M.)

group.name: Practice English And Meet New People In Boston

results.description: Our game nights are always tons of fun! Bring a vegan dish (no meat, fish, poultry, dairy, honey, eggs) to share and a party game, if you like. (I have 2 here that people left, so we'll probably play those first.) I will have water and tea, but if you would like something else to drink, please bring it. Also, in an effort to be environmentally aware, if you could bring a place setting (dish, fork, spoon, cup/glass, cloth napkin). I have enough for some, but usually not all. Call for address:[masked]-1551.
results.name: Potluck/Game Night Is Back!

results.description:
DELICIOUS DINNER

(and Take-Out)

Prepared by

DAVID SNIECKUS

- MACROBIOTIC CHEF AND COUNSELOR - At 7 p.m.

at David’s, Margaret’s and Abigail's home in Newton, MA

September 18, 2015 Menu

Creamy Chickpea Soup

Wild Rice

Seitan, Burdock, and Carrot Saute with Kale

Wakame and Scallions/Chives with Mustard

Butternut Squash

Pickled Beets and Raw Salads

Tahini Pudding and Berries

Kukicha Tea

(see detailed logistics below.)

**************************

Followed by a presentation from 8 to 10 pm on

Brahma Vihara - Metta (Loving-kindness)

with Whispering Deer

The practice of loving-kindness cultivates an openness of heart – a heart that is not afraid and one that does demand any particular result. It encourages the heart to remain open rather than to shut down in the face of pain and suffering – to remain at ease under all conditions. Loving-kindness cultivates a sense of good heartedness towards ourselves which then radiates outward engendering generosity and care for others happiness and well-being. Come and join us in experiencing a love that has no preference and is unbound.

Donation welcome.

About Whispering Deer

Meditation is my primary spiritual practice. Each year, I spend 8 weeks in silence, working with various meditation techniques, accessing deep states of consciousness and expanded awareness. This work has led me to experience the transformative power of the awakened heart, resulting in the development of the Brahma Vihara workshops. The benefits I have received are innumerable and immeasurable. Nothing would please me more than to share what I have learned with others.

For more information, go to: https://sites.google.com/site/whisperingdeermeditation/

Upcoming Brahma Vihara workshops with Whispering Deer:

October 23, 2015: Brahma Vihara - Karuna (Compassion)

November 13, 2015: Brahma Vihara - Mudita (Appreciative Joy)

November 20, 2015: Brahma Vihara - Upeka (Equanimity) **************************

Most ingredients are organic and of the highest standards.

Come be in community

and enjoy the healthiest meal on planet earth!

Call (617)[masked] or e-mail [masked]
for reservations and directions.

Please rsvp no later than noon on Friday.

Sliding scale of $20 - $35/meal.

(Note: Preferred payment is by cash or check.)
(Let David know if interested in helping him cook in exchange for a free meal. Prerequisite: One of David's cooking classes, unless experienced.)

(Please contact us if you'd like to lead a discussion opener based upon a topic of your choice.)

Feel free to pass on to other friends and kindred spirits!
results.name: Friday dinner and presentation: Brahma Vihara - Metta - w/ Whispering Deer

group.name: Holistic Health Speaker Series and Study Group

results.description:
I am hosting les vin d'Alsace region known for its Gewürztraminer and  Rieslings there are also wines made out of the pinot noir grapes which are pale red. Please bring any bottle you wish to evaluate and enjoy. Price can be be from $20 - $40 or more....


If you wish to bring food please do or contribute $10.

Bring your wine in a paper bag and 4 glasses.


Let's enjoy la joie de vivre 

Cheers,

Cyril
results.name: Vins d'Alsace

results.description:
We are on the second floor of the office/clubhouse building. If for some reason, the front door isn't propped open, come around the back of the clubhouse, up the outside back stairs to the second floor, where you can enter through the sliding glass door on the deck.

You CAN park along the road or in the "future resident" spots, but please do not take the spots in front of the building next door that are "resident only."

You can bring food and drink. If you want to grab dinner on the way in, there is a good and inexpensive Italian place almost across the street that also does take-out (Linguine's) and there is a Chipotle's nearby but expect to wait in line for 40 minutes on a Friday night. Feel free to bring your own games and snacks/drinks. We do have a small kitchen available to us.

Don't forget - Randy is paying Meetup like $15 a month to run this group. Consider chipping in a couple bucks each year to help defray his costs.

group.name: Whole Health Dinners, Gatherings, and Presentations

results.description:
<We'll sing inspiring songs, come together in community, and let the sound in each of us be heard.>


Let your heart sing!
Do you love to sing, but…?
Do you yearn to step into fuller expression? To be heard? To hear yourself? In a circle tradition, and with love and acceptance, we will sing songs of inspiration and gently embrace and allow our voices to express from within. It doesn’t matter how you sound, because this is about
• the energy that flows (and doesn’t care if we’re in tune),
• opening a door to your heart and giving it wings to express,
• bringing the wisdom of many song traditions into our daily lives, and
• the power of supportive community.
In a SpiritSong circle, we learn to listen deeply and open to the beautiful spaces within, and we are heard without judgment. We cultivate authentic expression. We share in the healing joy of sound!

You are warmly invited to join us at this, our monthly drop-in SpiritSong evening,  in Stow, MA.
Sign-up here to reserve your place.
Led by Carolyn Sprague, certified SpiritSong Facilitator (trained by Shawna Carol).
Hosted by MariePatrice Masse of Inspiring Life.
Call or email MariePatrice for more info: [masked][masked]-0897.
Heartfelt Donations appreciated.

Does this event inspire you?  If you're inspired by Personal growth, Transformation, Healing, Awakening, Spirituality, Community, Nature and Ecology you'll want to check out our other
 INSPIRING LIFE events   www.tinyURL.com/InspiringLife

 contact [masked],
 or look for our events right here on the Personal Growth Network.
results.how_to_find_us: Allow extra time your first time coming here. Call us if you need to be guided in- 978-579-0897.
results.name: Inspiring Life: SpiritSong Evening

results.name: Meditation

results.description:
Three hours of piano karaoke at The Green Room --- a wonderfully intimate venue in the heart of Union Square, Somerville.

Much more info here:

http://www.pianokaraoke.net

and

FAQ page

COST: $5+ requested donation at the door (to defray venue rental, piano tuning fees, Meetup organizer fees, Soundcloud fees, etc.)

NOTE: The exterior door of The Green Room is a little tricky --- lift the handle UP instead of pulling it down!

PARKING: metered parking is available in the neighborhood. It's also OK to park in non-metered spots on residential streets if you do so for two hours or less. We've noted one ticket so far, so if you're staying longer than two hours, please plan on shifting your car's parking space before two hours go by.
results.name: Piano Karaoke at The Green Room

results.description:
The Knickerbocker Club Open Mic Night is a great time! Performers usually get 5 or 6 songs here with the opportunity to get back up after the list is completed.  So come prepared. And be ready for some of the cheapest beer around. And try the fried pickles!!

~Christine
results.name: Open Mic Night - The Knickerbocker Club, Lowell, MA

group.name: Open Mic Night - For musicians of all skill levels

venue.name: Wild Rover Bar Boston - 1 Block from Faneuil Hall

results.description:
Biagio puts on a great party and has graciously invited the members of the Boston Social and Cultural Club.  Biagio rented the whole 2nd floor of the Wild Rover to make this an awesome private party.

PLEASE DO NOT DOUBLE RSVP! ----PLEASE RSVP IN ONE GROUP ONLY!! 

Join the legendary crazy dancing at our Mix +Mingle Meetup Private Party for 120+ members with our own DJ, dance area, 2 bars +apps/food from 7-9PM.

7-9PM is the Social Mixer which the best because it allows you to get to know your fellow Meetup members. After 9PM the crazy dancing + loud music starts so please do not complain, since members come to dance to loud music after 9PM.

Bonus FREE KARAOKE on 1st  floor if you want to kick it KARAOKE style.

Its the party everyone loves since its the starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

The BEST part!...Come between 7 and 8:20PM to get 1 included (FREE) drink ticket good for any beer, wine, or mixed drink! (Sorry no shots or top-shelf liquor). This 1 Drink ticket will expire at 8:20PM sharp!!.....Please don't forget to TIP your bartender for the included drink!

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist band to wear so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

1. Biagio collects $10 cash from everyone, but the invited Larger Meetup Group Head Organizers and some of the  Social Fun Organizers..

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Biagio at the top of the stairs.

Its the party everyone loves since its he starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist bands to  so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

results.description:
The theme for our September 18 session will be on Creating Deep Relaxation and Inner Peace.  Our guided meditations sessions will be held the 1st and 3rd Friday evening each month.  Other meetup events will begin again soon, too! (Send me your ideas and requests!)

Feeling stressed and generally "pooped out"?  Whether you do or not, getting into a deeply relaxed state and feeling inner peace will be good for your mind, body and soul. 


• You'll be renewed and recharged. 


• You'll gain inspirational insights for living with greater ease and joy. 


• You'll learn simple techniques to continue to use on your own. 


• You'll connect with wonderful, like-minded folks.

• You'll release resistance, and thus be more of a vibrational match to manifest what you desire.


• And it just feels so good!


Please join us for another evening of pure relaxed bliss; insight, inspiration, and upliftment!  I make it really easy for you, too. So mark your calendars to save the date, RSVP YES, and we'll see you there!

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 classes, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check; good for any 4 guided meditation sessions within 4 months of purchase).   Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20. You do not have to commit to attending every class, however, the more regularly you attend, the more you will benefit!  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.


Here's the general description of these meditation sessions, held the 1st and 3rd Friday evenings each month:

Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

By participating in these guided meditations classes, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

Techniques to help you shift your perspective and experience of issues in your life causing you stress in some form, and to shift to Spirit perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each class to help build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

Each class consists of 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss.  Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy.  It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do.  I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much.  Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations!  I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the basement level Roots Studio; (Note: extra parking available on Stratford St., by the Dairy Queen. Do not park at the DQ).
results.name: Guided Meditations for Deep Relaxation and Inner Peace

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

results.description:
The presence of the Angelic Realm is among us all, in every moment.

They are here to support us, to guide us, to heal us while we are here on this physical plane.

Many experience signs from the angels - feathers, pennies, 444 (triple or reoccurring numbers), a song on the radio at just the right moment, a call from someone you we just thinking about are just a few.

We must remember as part of our choice to be here now, we were given divine free will in every moment to decide our next step, our thoughts, and our actions (and re-actions) in regards to our life.  Your angels want for you to call on them, to talk to them, to ask for their support and guidance - and then and only then can they attend to you and your life.

During this group we will call upon the Angelic Realm to support us and guide us through the process of Cutting the Cords to things, people, places, relationships, patterns, etc...that no longer serve us. We will invoke the energies of Archangel Michael to assist us in cutting cords as he is the Master Angel of this process.

We will then invoke the energies of Archangel Raphael - the Master Angel of Healing to heal all the those parts where the cords have been cut!  Filling us with light and love. We will also ask AA Raphael to heal our hearts of all hurts and past heartache, including those hurts that have been self-inflicted!

This will open you to a new, higher vibration and energies as you will then be able to 'hold' more light.  You will be in direct communion with your Angelic Support Team and ask for any specific guidance or questions that you may have.

Only high frequency loving energies will be called upon, so you will be safe and protected within this sacred space.

This is a great way to connect with your personal angelic support team, re-connect with your guardian angels or simply experience the loving and supportive energies of the angels!

Also a great space to connect with other spiritually minded individuals!

Energy Exchange $10

Nicol will be leading this group.

www.essencehealing.net to learn more about Essence of Healing

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
AID-MIT and MIT Sangam present a concert by Indian Ocean. Please check this link: http://indianocean.mit.edu/tickets/ to purchase tickets.
Keep a look out on this FB page https://www.facebook.com/events/1445050789131187/ for updates

India’s biggest underground success, Indian Ocean is a pioneering band in the Indian fusion and rock scene. Their sound can be described as “Indo-rock fusion with jazz-spiced rhythms that integrates shlokas, sufism, environmentalism, mythology and revolution.”Formed in the early 90s, Indian Ocean has spearheaded the Indian rock scene and is one of India’s few politically conscious bands. A cult band in its own right, the group has amalgamated Indian folk music with Western rock. Culling their lyrics from a variety of languages, including Hindi, Kashmiri, Bengali, Sanskrit and even Aramaic, their music ranges from rocking political anthems to meditative spiritual ballads.


Setting the precedent from their first self-titled album (which was the highest selling album by an Indian band at the the time), Indian Ocean has earned rave reviews from the critics and audiences alike. Their third album Kandisa, released in 2000, is considered one of the most important, best-loved albums of contemporary Indian music, while their latest album Tandanu featuring collaborations with metal, Bollywood, and Indian classical artists, has been hailed as “an album that awakens a new consciousness” by Rolling Stone India.

The band’s fame and following has not been limited to India’s shores – as their much-stamped passports attest, they are India’s leading global band. Since 2001, Indian Ocean has gracing stages across the US, Canada, UK, Europe, Australia and South East Asia. They’ve performed and collaborated with the celebrated violinist Pandit L. Subramaniam, legendary American folk singer Pete Seeger, virtuoso Japanese trumpeter Terumasa Hino and more.
results.name: Indian Ocean Concert at MIT

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours

results.description:
Special note about parking:  Please do not park at the Kickstand Cafe parking lot. You can park on the street a few blocks away from Arlington center.

Full marathoners (21 miles):

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/290549097


Half marathoners (12 miles):

http://www.mapmyrun.com/routes/view/290554161

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course.

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM. 

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
Nutritarians + Bean Town = A One-Day Intensive Made in Heaven


LEARN MORE


Boston is famous for its beans, and beans are a key component of Dr. Fuhrman’s Nutritarian diet—what could be more perfect?

New Englanders will have a chance to join Dr. Fuhrman as he leads a Nutritarian One-Day Intensive on Saturday, September 19, 2015 at the Royal Sonesta Hotel in Boston, MA.

This day of lectures will inspire you to begin (or continue) your journey to weight loss and optimal health as you explore the core concepts of the Nutritarian diet. You’ll learn about food addiction, and how to break free from its devastating effects.

You’ll also discover the importance of micronutrients, the joys of eating a nutrient-dense, plant-rich diet, and how nutritional excellence can help you lose weight, as well as prevent and reverse chronic disease. Dr. Fuhrman will give you the knowledge and tools to help you maximize your health, live disease-free and increase your longevity.

In addition to the lectures, you will enjoy a delicious Nutritarian-style boxed lunch. There will also be a book signing with Dr. Fuhrman.

Visit the event page for more information or to register.

Visit the event page for more information or to register.


Flemington, NJ 08822 
Phone: (908)[masked]
www.DrFuhrman.com

• https://www.facebook.com/drfuhrman

• https://twitter.com/DrFuhrman

• http://www.drfuhrman.com/rss/whatshappening.feed

• https://www.youtube.com/user/drfuhrman

Nutritarian
One-Day Intensive: 
Boston, MA
September 19, 2015
8:00 AM – 5:00 PM (EST)  

* Share on google_plus

* Share on linkedin

* Share on twitter

* Share on facebook

* Sharing Services

This one-day intensive will inspire you and guide you on your journey toward optimal health and Nutritarian living.

Spend the day with Dr. Fuhrman in the Boston suburb of Cambridge at the elegant Grand Ballroom in the Royal Sonesta Boston Hotel for a day of informative and inspiring lectures. By the end of the day, you will hold the keys to maximize your health through superior nutrition, live disease-free, and push the envelope of human longevity.

This event is complemented by a catered Nutritarian boxed lunch and a book signing.

Agenda (PDF)

DETAILS

DIRECTIONS

PRICE/REGISTER

During the lectures you will learn about:Achieving superior health and your ideal weightResolving food addictionReversing and preventing heart disease & diabetesFighting cancer and maximizing longevityPreparing Nutritarian recipes and menu planningAlso included:A book signing with Dr. FuhrmanA delicious Nutritarian lunch

Come spend an information-filled day with Dr. Fuhrman and learn how to reverse disease, lose weight, and prevent heart disease and cancer without drugs or fad diets!

CE credits available!

This activity qualifies for 4.25 CEUs. Participants should claim only the credit commensurate with the extent of their participation in the activity.* Certificates will be provided. See event coordinator upon completion of the event to receive your certificate.

*An additional fee of $10 applies to register for CE Units.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Make Your Next Stop Better Health!
Houston, Boston, or New Jersey—You Choose!

Dr. Fuhrman is hosting his popular Nutritarian events at three uniquely wonderful destinations.  

Whether you seek to reinforce your commitment or need to learn more to get started, hear firsthand from Dr. Fuhrman how you can enjoy a healthier life. 

Bring your friends and loved ones. 

Come get motivated. 

Learn tips while enjoying hotel amenities. 

Relax as you meet other like-minded people. 

Transform your life and take back control of your health. 

Listen as Dr. Fuhrman explains the latest nutritional research and how you can easily apply it to your own daily living. 

Don’t miss this lifesaving information for you and those you care about. 

Dr. Fuhrman’s transformative Nutritarian events offers reassurance, motivation and the tools you need.

Come join us!
* Boston, Massachusetts - September 19, 2015
* Houston, Texas - October 9-11, 2015
* Bridgewater, New Jersey - November 20–22, 2015

results.description:
Backroads ride to Parkers Maple Barn for lunch.

Parker`s Maple Barn has been a family establishment since the late 1960`s. It began with nothing more than a small Sugar House by the original Parker family and has grown to become a very popular country restaurant serving hearty breakfasts and lunch. The Corn-Crib gift shop features all of ourmaple products along with many unique gifts like our maple syrup gift baskets and maple syrup tins. The Sugar House still produces maple syrup following the old tradition of wood-fired evaporators.

Located just over the border from Massachusetts you will find the quiet town of Mason, New Hampshire, the home of Parker`s Maple Barn. Mason is a quaint country town historically known as the boyhood home of "Uncle Sam", a fact that this town is still proud of today! 

Meeting details to follow

results.description:
Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

==========

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to climb one of the NH 4,000 Footers - Carrigain. This peak, along with it's fire tower, has some of the best views in the White Mountains. We will use Signal Ridge Trail to reach the summit and then turn around to retrace our steps to get back to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months. 

Group size will be limited to 12 people.

Guests aren't permitted. Everyone must be a member of the group.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.2 miles and climb about 3,700 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours to complete this trip. This event is considered to be INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

You are ultimately responsible for your own safety. Use these links for more information about the summits that we'll climb and the trails we'll use to get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/13-Mt-Carrigain-4700

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.0933966660005&lon=-71.44757652599964&site=all&smap=1#.VBuboUtNZ_Y

=== What to Bring ===

I will update this event description a few days beforehand when I know more about what we can expect to encounter. Use this link for a list of items needed for most three season day hikes:

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip.

=== Directions ===

We will meet in the parking lot on the east side of Sawyer River Road about two miles south of Route 302. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 174 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours and 56 minutes to drive there. Use this link for customizable driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/KtH3q

</a>

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the <a href="http://www.hikesafe.com/">Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: NH4K ... Carrigain (Intermediate)

•  Data Science Innovation is fundamental to many of today’s exciting startups. These innovative products and services have data science at their core. The Data Science Innovation Day will give you direct insight into this exciting and growing field. 


•  At the Data Science Innovation Day, you will learn the latest innovations in data science. We will cover topics and workshops that include but are not limited to predictive analytics, machine learning, text analytics, and data visualization. results.description:
Please join members and guests for an Open House on September 19, 2015. 

Attend the meeting at 9:00 am then plan to spend some time after the meeting (10:45-11:45) to enjoy pastries and coffee, socialize with members and guests, learn more about Toastmasters and meet new friends. We are looking forward to meeting you!

[Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]


Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left.
results.name: Open House at Watertown Saturday Toastmasters Club Meeting, All are Welcome!

results.description:
So it's that time of the year when the leaves are changing colors and we say good-bye to summer. But don't fret! This means it's apple picking season! The honeycrisp, mcintosh, galas, and others are just waiting to be picked and eaten. So join us for a day of fun picking apples or peaches to celebrate the beginning of fall.

The weather will be in the high 70s and low 80s; a great time to be out and about picking apples. Hope you can join us! :)

1. We'll first meet up at the Kitchen store; look for the signs after parking. There is a good amount of parking to your left/right when you drive in since we're arriving there early. The orchards open at 10:00 AM so please be sure to arrive ON TIME and be sure to know which 'pick your own' you want. Most of us will likely share a peck or 1/2 bushel so please bring some cash with you.

peck = 10 lbs for $26; admits 4 people

1/2 bushel = 20 lbs for $26; admits 6 people

Link to website with prices: http://www.tougasfarm.com/pickcond.htm

2. We'll meet up again at the Kitchen at 12:00 PM at the picnic tables outside. That should give everyone enough time to pick apples, tour the farm, and fill up on kettle corn, doughnuts, or cider :)

3. Lunch (optional) will be at Mandarin Buffet, 132 Turnpike Rd. in Westborough. It's a decent buffet at a reasonable price.


Transportation is your own responsibility. If you need a ride or can give a ride be sure to indicate that. Indicate where you are coming from and what T stop you can meet at so carpools can be coordinated smoother. Our members are pretty good about offering carpools, be sure to help out w/ gas. Suggested carpool fee is $5.
results.name: Fall Apple Picking & lunch (optional)

results.description:
Free Durosvis Dive 7 for attendees and more than $2,500 in prizes include Tango Tablets!

We are excited to bring together developers, designers and visual/graphics and sound artists to build software which using Google's Project Tango's sensors, 3D vision and mapping using Unity, Android OpenGL+Java or Android OpenGL+C/C++. Let's stretch and have fun.

We have limited space so registration is by invitation. Please fill out this form to request an invitation. 

This event is coorganized with GDG, Boston Android, Boston Virtual Reality and the Boston Unity Groups


We'll have TAs with experience on different aspects of VR development and we'll work in teams. 

Smartphones are filled with sensors, but choices haven't changed for a while until Tango - let's explore the frontier of what might be built with Tango's additional sensors.

Swag and PrizesWe have swag, food and winners will take home a Tango Tablet. At the end of the day we'll hoist a few beers.

</a>

<a href="http://4.bp.blogspot.com/-alZHG_u2BfU/VfhswK6eapI/AAAAAAAASBE/SmnGy7LPl3s/s1600/Dive%2BHeadset.jpg">

Attendees will receive a Durovis Dive 7 headset ($120 value) that bring Virtual Reality to 7 inch tablets (provide your own 7" phone).

If you'd like to join with a small group of us, please complete this Project Tango Hackathon form (Google Account Required).


Don't RSVP here! Attendees will be selected from those who complete the application form.

What is Project Tango?

In Google's own words - Project Tango technology gives a mobile device the ability to navigate the physical world similar to how we do as humans. Project Tango brings a new kind of spatial perception to the Android device platform by adding advanced computer vision, image processing, and special vision sensors.

results.description:
Last minute decision here: I'll come up with a route tonight, but basically I'll start in Concord Ctr. and weave together some mix of the routes we all love for a 25-30 mile loop.

---------------------

Here's the map and cue-sheet, 27.4 miles:

http://ridewithgps.com/routes/10440612

When: 
Let's meet up at 9:45 am and be ready to start at 10:00 am. Aiming to be back by 1:00 pm.

Where: 
The public parking lot on Keyes Rd, right in the center of Concord (it has public restrooms and a water fountain).

Who: 
You need to be okay with a 12-15 mph pace. We will wait for everyone at the top of major hills and at confusing intersections, but please don't sign up if you can't keep at least a 12 mph average pace with relatively few stops.

What's required: 
* Road bike in good repair 
* Bike helmet 
* At least one full large water bottle (you can refill at lunch) 
* Spare tube, and air

What's recommended: 
* Basic repair tools
* Snack 
* Cell phone

A few lunch options:

• If you bring your own, then the picnic tables by the brook right off the parking lot are ideal. 

• Main Streets Market & Cafe has a small take-out shop right next to these picnic tables that serves "Burritos, Pizzas, Hotdogs, Sandwiches, Smoothies & Ice Cream". They sometimes get too crowded and run out of stuff. Also, I walked by them today and noticed that it now says cash only.

• Their main restaurant is in the same building, with an entrance on Main St. It would take too long to eat there, but they are great if you are looking for ice coffee or homemade lemonade to go. 

• Helen's Restaurant is across the street, at 17 Main St. Standard coffee and sandwiches, cash only.

• Haute Coffee is in an alley on the right, 100' down Walden St. Fancy coffee and sandwiches.
results.name: 27 mile loop out of Concord Ctr

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the triangle between Magnolia and Thorndike Fields, just off the bike path.
results.name: (Arlington) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

Run Details: Meet up with The Most Informal Running Club Ever at 10:00am for the weekly Saturday Fun Run. We'll split up into groups depending on the turnout for distance and time goals for 4, 6 or 7 mile loops. It's your choice!

What to expect: a seriously fun group of runners who definitely do not take running too seriously . We will meet, chat, RUN, stretch, chat, EAT BREAKFAST and then leave. It's that easy.

Breakfast Details : Between 11:15 and 11:30 (depending on how long we run) we will meet back at City Sports on Comm Ave. near Packards Corner for Pot Luck style brunch.

Contribute to a great breakfast with an item to share with the group (eggs, bagels, fruits, muffins, juice, bacon, potatoes, etc.) You're not obligated to bring anything, though, so please join us for breakfast after the run anyway.

ALL ABILITY LEVELS WELCOME!!!

Secret parking is accessible in the Star Market parking lot (just make sure you walk through Star Market. No one has ever been towed.)

Bring a friend, see you out there.


informalrunning.com


Read the BLOG

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who decide to join get a $10 deduction from membership!

Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

results.description:
The Israelite nation was developing its own identity and culture, but they were on the brink of destruction. The people wanted to find respect and recognition on the world stage, to feel secure and powerful, and to be prosperous and comfortable in their own homes.  But this was at a time when everyone was doing what was right in their own eyes.  Doesn't sound so different from today, does it?  But God wants to show us a better way--a man who will do all his will, a king after God's own heart.

Join us as we investigate the story of 1 Samuel and the different lessons for us!

results.description:
Let's bike the Cape Cod Rail Road Trail,

If you don't have a bike, you can rent one at the Dennis Cycle Center, http://www.denniscyclecenter.com/. Regarding if you are renting a bike or bringing your own, let's meet at 10:30 am at the Dennis Cycle Center.  There is plenty of parking and the trail is accessible from the parking lot.  Please plan ahead and allow enough travel time to arrive on time.  If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will be able to connect with the group.  


The Cape Cod Rail TrailThe Cape Cod Rail Trail follows a former railroad right-of-way for 22 miles through the towns of Dennis, Harwich, Brewster, Orleans, Eastham and Wellfleet. Its paved surface, few hills, and well-marked automobile crossings make it ideal for cyclists. The trail has a wide unpaved shoulder on one side to accommodate horseback riding, walkers, and runners.


There are many opportunities to get off the trail and visit a beach. Food and water are also readily available and public restrooms can be found at Nickerson State Park, Salt Pond Visitors Center at Cape Cod National Seashore and the National Seashore Headquarters.

http://www.mass.gov/eea/agencies/dcr/massparks/region-south/cape-cod-rail-trail.html

http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/ccrt.pdf


Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement.  For events to be successful, I need to know who to expect and how many.  For example, if the group is very large, I may need to make special accommodations with any related venues or facilities. 


Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, no problem, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group. 

Trail map - http://www.mass.gov/eea/docs/dcr/parks/trails/ccrt.pdf

Joana

*Register by 9/18 and Check-In from 11pm to 1pm on 9/19*


Get Your Tickets Now(Link Below): 

http://thegreatbostonscavengerhunt.eventbrite.com/?aff=DZ

Event Details

Solve clues to find our favorite landmarks and pubs around Boston.  Use those clues to check into locations or complete challenges to win CASH PRIZES!  

Prizes: 

Grand Prizes:  $500 CASH - Individual with the most points

1st - 3rd prize, based on total points earned: Giftcards from our sponsors and scavenger hosts.

Tickets:

$20 - Advance Tickets

$30 at the door if we are not sold out

All tickets include special swag, and supplies you need to complete the challenges.  

The game:

* Arrive at Central Wharf to check in and pick up your trivia packet between 11am and 1pm.  

* Plan your day and CHOOSE YOUR OWN ADVENTURE TO EARN POINTS.  Whether you want to explore Boston and learn about landmarks and trivia, or relax at our favorite local pubs and have drinks, there will be more than enough ways to earn points, and have a fun, memorable afternoon.

* Return to Central Wharf by 4pm to be considered for a prize, then enjoy the after party!

* Race around downtown Boston using the clues given.  Each clue will lead to a specific location, where you will complete a short challenge in order to receive the points.  

* Types of challenges include tweeting your trivia answer on twitter, instagraming creative photos, or doing a quick and fun activity.  Representatives at some locations will be stamping your packet as back up so we know the challenge was completed successfully.

* There will be bonus scavenger hunt clues that will be tweeted by @bostonypa, giving you the opportunity for more points.  

* There will be 20 bonus points awarded to our favorite instagram photo or favorite tweet for each challenge that has one.  

* We will be tracking everyone's progress back at Central Wharf.  In order to be counted, everything posted on social media must include the hashtag #BYPAHunt

* Upon returning with your packets, we will give you points for completing challenges, answering trivia questions correctly, and start confirming social media activity that we hadn't caught during the day.

* Enjoy the after party while we tally the numbers.  

Rules to make this FUN and FAIR:

* Scavenger Hunt packets must be picked up by 1pm, and returned by 4pm.

* Each person participating must be registered. This makes it fair, and ensures that no location runs out of supplies.  Anyone playing with an unregistered person will be disqualified.

* Event will be held rain or shine.

* Please drink responsibly.

Advance Tickets until 9/18(Link Below): 

 http://thegreatbostonscavengerhunt.eventbrite.com/?aff=DZ

results.description:
Mark your calendars for this special double feature lunch and lecture to inaugurate our Fall series, with 2 provocative guests and a pizza lunch provided by Greater Boston Humanists and your donations at the event.

JOEL PRIMACK is a Professor of Astrophysics and Physics at the U. of California, Santa Cruz, and an eminent cosmologist. After helping to create what is now called the "Standard Model" of particle physics, Primack began working in cosmology in the late 1970s and he became a leader in the new field of particle astrophysics. He is one of the principal originators and developers of the theory of Cold Dark Matter, which has become the basis for the standard modern picture of structure formation in the universe. 

At 11:30 he and his wife Nancy Abrams will do a presentation on 'Current Concepts of Our Universe'.  


We'll break for lunch at 12:15 or so. 

At 1 pm NANCY ABRAMS will speak to us about her recent book "A God That Could Be Real: Spirituality, Science, and the Future of Our Planet". Ms. Abrams urges us to a redefinition of 'God' consistent with cutting edge Science. According to Abrams, all humans are hard-wired with what Carl Jung called a “god-capacity,” prompting people throughout history to seek a higher power, as she did during her personal recovery experience, about which we'll hear. She conceives an 'emerging God' that can be seen as the guiding force of science. 'God,' she proposes, has emerged from our species, and is as real as the economy, the government, or the worldwide web, which are all emergent phenomena.

We'll listen to both presentations and discuss these ideas as a way to come to grips with the power of religious belief, scientific conceptions of the Universe, and ways to promote humanism as we understand it.

Pizza will be catered and include vegetarian and hopefully also vegan options. We ask that you make a small contribution to defray the cost of the food, during the event.

Free PARKING will be available in the Littauer Lot of Harvard University near the Science Center (Enter the Dworkin Science Quadrangle from Oxford St. and proceed to the end of the road to the parking area near the Science Center behind Littauer Library. If nervous, leave a note in your dashboard that you are at the Humanist event at PBH.)
results.name: Lunch and Lecture: Primack and Abrams on Cosmology and 'Spirituality'

A challenging, motivating, and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long day of work.

TFW signature workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, which has created world champions in multiple professional sports, and is individually-adapted for every person that takes part, even beginners!

Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives.

If you want to have fun and lose fat, gain strength, and improve your confidence and health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend.

results.description:
(A set of 6 Saturday classes)

Rapier – The word evokes images of duels, high adventure, and swashbuckling. Have you had a desire to learn how these swords were used in combat during the Renaissance era? Much more than shouting “En Garde!” and assuming a guard stance; competent warriors fought with systems that included various ways to attack and defend, footwork, timing, and even rules of dueling, all based on a sophisticated understanding of body mechanics, mathematics and philosophy.

The 16th century was a period of change for the sword. No longer relegated to the battlefield; the sword changed as its wear became commonplace in society. Blades slimmed and guards became more elaborate as the sword evolved into a nimble thrusting weapon worn by commoner and noble alike. As a result, a number of fencing schools opened to capitalize on their growing popularity. The golden age of rapier study dawned around 1550; numerous masters publishing fencing system manuals over the century to follow, with topics including rapier, off-hand companions such as the dagger, buckler and cape, long sword, quarterstaff, pole arm, dagger alone, and grappling.

Our six-week Novice Rapier course will introduce the basic techniques and vocabulary of rapier fencing, enabling students to begin their study of period combat and the Art of Defence. The course will be taught by Charles and Robert, rapier scholars and Schole of Defence instructors.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

We invite you to come join the scholars and combatants of our Schole!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes [August 22, 29, and September 5, 12, 19 and, 26] and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  Class materials will be sent via email before the first session.)

results.description:
NOTE: this is meetup is on a Saturday rather than the usual Sunday. 


We have rented 3 badminton courts at the BU Fitness & Recreation Center (regulation full sized courts).  The BU facility is immaculate and a fantastic place to play.


The fee (payable online when you RSVP) gets you into the BU Fitness & Recreation Center to play badminton for an hour and a half.  Part of the fee is for the court time and the rest is for your meetup group to cover other expenses, i.e. rackets, shuttlecocks/birdies, meetup.com fees. All fees collected go to pay the Group's expenses.

We have rackets and shuttles for everyone!

Expect to play doubles. The host can help to match up pairs but members are free to join in any game they want.  The courts are reserved only for Boston Badminton members.

Before asking a question, please read through the following FAQs:

Q: The meetup is full, can I come regardless and pay at the event?
A: No, there is limited space to make sure everyone gets to play. A few spots typically open up before the event.

Q: It's my first time, how do I find you?
A: Go to the BU Fitness & Recreation Center reception (see directions below), and tell them you're here with Boston Badminton. They'll tell you where the courts are, check you're on the list, and make you sign a waiver. The meeting point is on the courts.

Q: I am a BU student, do I get a discount?
A: No, BU charges us the same regardless of whether participants are at BU or not.


Directions:
Please click here for a google map to The BU Fitness & Recreation Center.  The easiest way to get to the FitRec center from within Boston is to take the Green Line (B)-Boston College to Saint Paul St.  Parking is limited but available.  Please click here for parking information.

Plan to grab a drink locally after if we have interest.

The club has full locker room and shower facilities.

Note: In addition to agreeing to the Meetup's Liability Waiver, all members must sign a Waiver of Liability Form in order to use BU's courts. This form is available at the front desk at the FitRec center.  We may ask you for your full name in order to help BU and the meetup comply with the liability procedures.

Let me know if you have any questions and I hope to see you there!

Liability Waiver

The purpose of the following Liability Waiver is to protect Boston Badminton meetup members and group leaders from liability in case of accident or injury. All members must agree to the Liability Waiver in order to participate in the group and its activities.

As part of my membership to Boston Badminton on Meetup.com (hereinafter “Boston Badminton”), I hereby freely and voluntarily agree to the following Release, Acknowledgment of Risk, and Waiver of Liability:

In consideration of the opportunity to participate in events, activities, classes, and programs conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates in any venue, and to use equipment located therein, I, on behalf of myself and my minor children, do hereby release, hold harmless and forever discharge and agree not to sue Boston Badminton and its trustees, officers, agents, founders, members, volunteers and employees (together, "Meetup.com Group") from any and all claims, responsibilities or liabilities for injury or damages resulting from or arising out of my or my family’s use of, presence in, or participation in activities conducted at any venue rented or owned by Boston Badminton, whether or not caused by the ordinary negligence of Boston Badminton. I understand, recognize and acknowledge that certain activities conducted by Boston Badminton or taking place in venues rented or owned by Boston Badminton are potentially hazardous. I also acknowledge that it is my responsibility to follow instructions for any activity or use of equipment, and to seek help from the volunteers if I have any questions. I further understand that, notwithstanding precautions taken by Boston Badminton, sports and fitness activities involve a risk of injury and/or death. I/we are voluntarily participating in these activities and using equipment and machinery with knowledge of the dangers involved. I hereby agree to expressly assume and accept any and all risks associated with my participation in activities conducted by Boston Badminton and its affiliates. I have read the foregoing and hereby agree to be bound by same.

This event is sponsored by Binnovative.org - details below.  I will not in fact attend but am cross-posting by request.  Please contact Eriko for information and not me, and please be sure to visit their site and follow their registration procedure.   Thanks.

Eriko
Hi! My name is Eriko and I am a founder/CEO of Binnovative.org, a non-profit organization based in Boston. I’m reaching out to you for help promoting an awesome event I think your members would love to be a part of. I would greatly appreciate it if you could forward this email to the group. Binnovative is organizing a business plan competition for Santouka Ramen, a global ramen restaurant chain originally from Japan. They just open a store at Harvard square this year but looking for further expansion in Boston area. This will be a great opportunity for attendees to gain real-world experience in a team setting, and the chance to be involved with one of the most successful ramen chains from Japan. The competition is open to anyone in the Boston area through online registration; we welcome teams or individuals to join (Individual attendees will form the team at 9/19 kick off).
The winning team may see their proposal actually executed by the Santouka Ramen management with support of that team’s members. Teams with high-quality submissions will receive great prizes including fine condiments from Japan. Key event dates are listed below: 9/19 1:00pm-4:00pm (Sat) @ Cambridge Innovation Center: Kick-off and team formation for individual attendees
9/26 1:00pm-3:00pm (Sat) @ Cambridge Innovation Center: Kick-off event for team attendees
9/27 10:00am-11:00am (Sun) @ Santouka Harvard Square: Santoka Tour + Ramen Tasting
10/3 1:00pm-6:30pm (Sat) @ Cambridge Innovation Center: Final Presentation * We have info session as well !!
9/10 6:30pm-7:30pm (Thu) @ Cambridge Innovation Center: Information Session (Optional) For more information and registration, visit http://www.binnovative.org/biz-competition-2015­ Thank you very much for your help, and please don’t hesitate to email me ([masked] or bizchallenge@binnovative­.org) any questions you may have.

JOIN US FOR OUR SEPTEMBER MEETUP! Because our usual venue in Natick is unavailable on this date, we'll be at the Donahue Center at Lasell College in Newton (see address above). For those who were at Lasell on August 1: This is a different building. On this campus map, the Donahue Center is #32 and the parking lot is P7. 

Easiest directions: Find your way to the Grove Street exit off Route 95/128. Follow Grove past T station on left, around curve to right, past Walker Center and Williams Elementary on left, then turn right on Myrtle. Immediately turn right into large parking lot (corner of Myrtle and Grove). There are two large buildings across the street from this lot; the Donahue Center is the one on the right. You may need to walk around front (facing a courtyard rather than the street) to enter. We'll be in Room 214.  

ATC SWAP THEMES: 

1. TV shows


2. Artist's Choice

DEMO/ACTIVITY:  TBD. 

WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. Just remember to remove anything that doesn't get picked up or sold--we can't leave anything behind.

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!
