results.description:
About the class: 

JavaScript is the world's most popular programming language for a reason -- it's the primary way to build interaction on the web. Learning JavaScript is a logical next step once you've learned HTML/CSS.

Many programming courses end up glossing over some of the tricky words -- 'variable', 'object', 'method' -- this course is especially designed for beginners new to programming concepts, so you'll learn to program with JavaScript. If those words are confusing to you now, no worries! You're exactly who we want to teach.

In this class, we will be covering: basic development concepts, writing our own JavaScript functions,browser events, web animation, and we will touch on the jQuery library. Students will exit this class with a good grasp of basic programming principles and the knowledge of how to manipulate HTML elements.

Schedule: 

2 Class sessions

Saturday, September 19th: 1:00pm - 5:00pm

Sunday, September 20th:  1:00pm - 5:00pm

PREREQUISITES: We suggest having a working knowledge of HTML and CSS as a prerequisite for this course. This course is specifically for beginners and we highly advise experienced developers to not take this class.


TECH REQUIREMENTS:

• Your laptop. (Note: a netbook or tablet is NOT a substitute!)

• A modern browser such as Chrome or Firefox installed.

• A text editor. We recommend Sublime Text 3 (It's free and available for Mac/PC/Linux).

About the teacher:

Catherine Farman has been building websites for over half her life, starting with HTML cobbled together on Geocities. Cat is currently a Technology & Innovation Fellow and Front End Developer for the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, where she builds standards-based websites using HTML, CSS and Javascript to help protect consumers in the financial marketplace. Cat teaches responsive web design, Javascript, and Sass courses for Girl Develop It. When she's not at a computer she likes to sew and watch soccer. Find her on Twitter @cfarm.

Want to help out at this class? We're always looking for TA's! Email the organizer at boston at girldevelopit dot com. 

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct.
results.name: JS101 - Intro to JavaScript (2-class weekend course)

results.description:
Brian Fitzpatrick will be doing a presentation on 3D printing at the next Meetup.


"3D printing also known as additive manufacturing is any of various processes used to make a three-dimensional object. In 3D printing, additive processes are used, in which successive layers of material are laid down under computer control. These objects can be of almost any shape or geometry, and are produced from a 3D model or other electronic data source. A 3D printer is a type of industrial robot..." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3D_printing 

Here are the details:


1. WHAT: Special Topic: 3D Printing


2. WHEN: September 19th, 2015 (this Saturday) from 1:00 PM - 3: 00 PM


3. WHERE:

We'll meet at the Braintree Library in the small conference room upstairs:


Thayer Public Library
798 Washington Street
Braintree, MA

4. WHY: Improve our technical knowledge and network. (Bring your business cards!)

5. ToDo: Please review the following article:


http://3dprinting.com/what-is-3d-printing/

6. Format: Presentation, demonstration, programming and discussions. This is a techie-led event. Bring your laptops!

7. Misc: Bring others interested with you!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be waiting upstairs in the small conference room in the Children section. If you do not find us, ask the librarian about the small group meeting in the conference room upstairs.

results.description:
{Do you seek greater inner peace?  Peacemakers is a group that helps you look at what "peace" means to you and helps you find how to create more peace in your life.} 

Our Topic This Evening Will ....

... provide you an opportunity to let go of tension, upset, and judgements so that you can experience greater peace.

Many of us have accepted living with tensions in our bodies, with upsets spoiling our mood at unexpected times, with judgments sneaking in. 

Come join us as we practice living our lives more peacefully. 

Peace is not being passive, submissive or indifferent. Peace is an active consciousness that we can learn to enter into, enriching our individual lives, our social situations and the world at large. 

During this evening, we will practice discovering the peace that is always present within us -- no matter what else is going on inside us or outside us in the world.   As we practice recognizing our inner core of peace, we become increasingly able to choose to live in that consciousness of inner peace, even at difficult times of our lives. 

We will look at where we unconsciously practice "against-ness", and learn to let go of that feeling of against-ness, to better work with reality and with the people who surround us. As we let go of "against-ness", we also let go of the upset feelings, prejudices, judgments, tenseness, etc. 

This meeting is sponsored by the Institute of Individual and World Peace (www.iiwp.org)

To Prepare ....

1) When do you feel "against-ness"? 


2) What are the physical signs of your against-ness? (e.g., tightness in throat)  

3) What emotional signs or mental beliefs could be signs of against-ness?

4) How could you be more effective if you were in peace even when bad things happened?

Our Leaders This Evening

https://fbcdn-profile-a.akamaihd.net/hprofile-ak-prn2/v/t1.0-1/c39.0.160.160/p160x160/537349_10152034344599510_1494662630_n.jpg?oh=e6044f0c169d6d3bcd9bce21fb142bbc&oe=5615B058&__gda__=1446013507_b7d9a5381ee0960560099851af0e879a

David Jenkins aspires to live his life more and more in peace. He considers himself a student of living the four principles of peace in his life. This is his highest priority. He is overjoyed to have been involved with the Peacemaker Project for several years. It expands peace in a quiet, loving way, one person at a time.

Emily Page delights in finding joy with others and as an inner process one moment at a time.She's been assisting with Boston Area PeaceMaker Meetings because the simple tools shared go so deep, work so fast and foster such harmony between participants, one session after another. 

Philosophy: The philosophy grounding this work is the realization that peace must start with the individual. One can not fight for peace. If we are going to be a conduit for peace, we must start with ourselves and be in peace. Peace is defined as the absence of againstness. If we can be in peace without being against ourselves or others or situations and encourage others to do the same, then we can be a conduit for peace. 

Facilitators Motivation: We aspire to live our lives more and more in peace. This intention is our highest priority. Participating in these meetings is one way to learn to live our lives more and more in peace. Encouraging others to do the same is strengthening for us all.
results.name: Create Inner Peace for a Happier Life (Peacemakers)

results.description:
At this meeting, we'll be learning how to determine if our ideas for side businesses are actually worth pursuing.  After all, who wants to waste months (or even years) chasing an idea that doesn't have any chance of being profitable?

We'll be discussing various inexpensive (or free) validation techniques.  Here are SOME of the topics we'll be covering:


- "Dry run" tests to test sales without first having invested in inventory


- PPC trials to gauge demand

- Setting up fake product pages to test sales funnels

- Using auctions to determine price points and fallback options

- Judging demand using keyword and customer research

- and how to avoid false positives when interviewing potential customers. 

We will also have a ~30 minute "hot seat" session, where Ping (one of our members) will present his current business idea and progress in an effort to get feedback from the group.
results.how_to_find_us: Enter on Mass Ave, walk in between the two red houses, look for a (very small) sign that says "Lexington Singapore School" on the left building (no. 807).
results.name: Idea Validation

results.description:
One of the greatest challenges to beekeeping in Massachusetts is getting One of the greatest challenges to beekeeping in Massachusetts is getting colonies through the winter. Last year Eastern MA beekeepers lost over 50% of their colonies over the winter months; the bees (and beekeepers) need all the help they can get. Come learn from a panel of experienced local beekeepers the techniques they have used and found to be successful for overwintering. The panel will include beekeepers tending Langstroth and Top Bar Hives (all of whom have successfully overwintered their hives). This session will include guidance on how to prepare your hive for winter, with time for Q & A after the panel discussion. 

There may also be an opportunity to go into a hive in our Teaching Apiary at BNC after the panel discussion, so please bring veils and dress appropriately if you are interested in this possible add-on to the session.


Instructors: Rebecca Rosenblum (TBH) & Ed Karle (Master Beekeeper, Langstroth)

Directions: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/boston-nature-center/directions

PRE-REGISTRATION ENCOURAGED: Boston Nature Center website (http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/program-catalog#program:keywords=Bee:program_code=41838) or contact Boston Nature Center at[masked]

Maximum # of Participants: 30

Cost: $5 for anyone who is not a Mass Audubon member
results.how_to_find_us: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/wildlife-sanctuaries/boston-nature-center/directions

***BOSTON MINSTRELS ANNUAL PARTY 2015***

Saturday, September 19, 2015

Join us for TWO events or just one and

celebrate being Minstrels together!!

Boston Harbor Cruise aboard "The Beacon"

From 3:30PM – 5:30PM  (singing of course!)!!

** MEET AT THE ROTUNDA behind the Harbor Hotel at 3PM sharp!!  The hotel has a huge arch and an American Flag hanging in it, can't miss it**

The Beacon is a classic Gatsby-era yacht, and is the most elegant power vessel in Boston Massachusetts.  Classic Harbor Line's motor Yacht Beacon is docked at Rowes Wharf, right behind the Boston Harbor Hotel, the yacht Beacon will be taking the Minstrels on a 2 hour tour of the harbor islands while we provide the music!  Free soft drinks and cash bar available.  Seats limited to 30 people on the cruise, right now we are at 20 people so there is plenty of room!  You can doodle (on line scheduler) here to check in:  http://doodle.com/poll/gpufnmh84baim2ib 

Can you bring a little appetizer for the cruise???

Cost of the cruise is $25.

Directions/Parking: MBTA – Red Line/South Station – walk north

 MBTA – Blue Line/Aquarium – walk south

Validated parking is $12 at Boston Harbor Hotel – Please car pool if you can!

Dinner at KINSALE at Government Center at 6PM

The band strikes up and the Minstrels do what they do best – sing and eat!!

A special 3 course dinner menu featuring salad or soup, choice of 4 entrees and dessert. Kinsale address:  2 Center Plaza across from City Hall http://www.classicirish.com/kinsale-directions.php

Price for dinner - $25 inclusive of tip, plus cash bar for drinks.

Directions/Parking:  MBTA – Red Line or Green /Park Street – walk to towards City Hall, Kinsale on the left.

Validated parking is free for 3 hours with dinner at Center Plaza Garage 1 Center Plaza (after 3 hours its $11 all day) – http://boston.lazparking.com/?np_lot=center-plaza-garage

If you park at Rowes and feel like walking between the boat and dinner, it is a .6 mile trek through the beautiftw city!  And vice versa if you park at Center Plaza and walk to the boat.

Our socials are a way for members of the community to get together, enjoying organized activities and casual conversation.  Several community leaders will be leading sections of the afternoon and will be available to talk.  And there will be dozens of people, many of whom you've met before at Heartbeat Salons and other personal growth work.

Folks who have come to our socials love them and want more...to mix, mingle and connect with like-hearted folks, to share and support each other in our personal growth journeys. 

There'll be fun activities that will deepen connections and spark meaningful friendships with like-hearted people. It's for everyone -- singles and marrieds, organizers and participants, old-timers and new-comers, young and old.

Our community is giving this party. Invite your friends & family.

{Note: This is a multi-site, multi-organizational Heart-to-Heart Community Social.}

Let the summer fun continue as we welcome in the Fall. 

We hope you will join us to mix, mingle & connect with like-hearted folks, to share and support each other in our personal growth & wellness journeys. 

Together with Organizers from other meetups & groups, we'll be bringing together all our peeps for a fun, fun unique social.

There are lots of fun activities planned that will deepen connections & spark meaningful friendships. It's for everyone, not just for singles. **************************************************
Mark H manifested his big dream to have a home that’s solar paneled and a very nice big backyard came along as a bonus! Thank you, Mark...for welcoming us to your lovely garden to enjoy!

Parking: easy, free street parking

Bring: Awesome YOU, friend(s) & LAWN CHAIR

Donation: $10 

Munchies & non-alcoholic refreshments will be provided. **************************************************

Ambassadors of the Heart-to-Heart Community Social:

Boston Law Of Attraction Meetup: Our desire is to bring together like-hearted folks interested in exploring ways of using the principles of Universal Laws, to attract more of what they want into their lives. 

www.meetup.com/lawofattraction-us 

Personal Growth Network: Connecting you to social support and diverse tools that help you to consciously create more success and more happiness in your life. 

www.meetup.com/Personal-Growth-Network 

Insight Boston: Teaching you practical tools to create a life you love and leading a more heart-centered life of greater loving, compassion, and acceptance. 

www.insightboston.org

www.meetup.com/boston-healers-network

www.meetup.com/nlp-100 

Tantric Intimacy Meetup: Learn practices to awaken and experience the fullest range of pleasure and ecstasy in your sexuality, fulfillment in your relationships, and passion and purpose in your life.

www.meetup.com/Tantric-Intimacy

You will not have a confirmed spot until I have your money, and I will not be purchasing tickets until then. So It is possible that by the time you get the money to me, the tickets are sold out. I will return the money if that happens. I have a Paypal account. If you want to pay me there, please send me a private message with your email included and I will provide all information. I do not know how the Paypal fees work, please
understand that I need to receive the full amount and will not return money via Paypal if it will cost me personal dollars to do so.

*My preference is that people sign up who I know or have at least met. If you pay and do not attend, you will lose the money unless you find someone to take your place.

Info I need on food choices:

Steak and lobster combo- $30.00: or
Steak alone- $20.00; or
Lobster alone- $20.00.

Dinner includes corn, baked potato, cole slaw, etc. Cash bar.

I put down 9 PM as the event end time, but we can stay as long as we like.

(FYI, the Malden Lodge of Elks has closed and is now merged with Medford)

results.description:
Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or a short walk from Park Street (Red Line) or Downtown Crossing (Orange Line). 

We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are not many RSVPs.


Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

Whoever is interested generally goes out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards, to eat family style - cost usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks other than tea/water, for which people pay their own way).
results.how_to_find_us: Usually at several tables pulled together at the highest point of the food court nearest the elevator.
results.name: Saturday Social Meetup at City Place

results.description:
It is the roaring 1920s and you are invited to quite a party! Rub elbows with the likes of gangsters, politicians, singers, and gamblers as they try to determine whom among them is guilty of murder. Wendy will be co-hosting this meetup with myself (Steven) to make a night of intrigue combined with some anime watching.

What is a "Murder Mystery Party"?

In essence, each attendee is assigned a character before the event and given information on that character. They then come to the event dressed up and receive further information about what they know, what their motivations are, and what they are trying to hide. The rest is mostly conversation, food + drink, anime, and just having fun.

For further background, in 2013, blood was spilled at my apartment at the funeral of Rick A. Rochester (http://goo.gl/FbVFtE). In 2014, we experienced a gathering of four immortal factions (Mage Guild, Were Clans, Vampyr House, and Fae Court) as they tried to determine who had been picking members of their faction off (http://goo.gl/nv5jic).


What is the plot of this party?

Murder at the Four Dueces: http://www.dinnerandamurder.com/games/4deuces.htm

The party cast consists of a wide variety of prohibition era roles from Gangstas to Gamblers. We will gather preferences and assign roles some time before the event.

I like the idea but don't have a costume...

We are not requiring anything spectacular and can assign you a character that will require the least amount of costume effort. A simple wig or even just an appropriate set of your normal clothes for the person would work. Seriously don't sweat the costume or feel like you will be viewed negatively for not putting effort into it.

I have anime cosplay. Can I wear that?

YES! We are the anime group, after all. ;) If you know what you might want to wear, please let us know so that we can try to assign a story character that might fit.

What is the cost?

There is no cost currently. However, this is a potluck. We will need people to bring food and drinks (including alcohol). Please post what you intend to bring and let us know if you have questions on what might be good.

RSVP Restrictions 

* Have attended at least one previous meetup with the group and not be a frequent no-show. This is because one is assigned a role beforehand and someone not showing up hurts the "plot" for all of those involved. Of course, we do understand last minute things come up - this restriction is just to help ensure that we will have a majority of the RSVPs there. You are allowed to bring up to two guests that haven't attended before (ie. you would be vouching for them).

AND 


* Be 18+ in age.
(NOTE: Of course, those under 21 cannot drink. Don't worry though! I will be joining those who can't or don't drink. It isn't needed to have fun nor is it the focus of this event).


Stuff happening beyond the murder mystery?

We will have one anime series on before we actually start as people arrive and get settled in. We will likely eat around the time of the ending reveal. Once the mystery is over, we will watch an episode or two of a series for those that want to still hang out afterwards a bit. 

Directions / Transportation

TBA

I have other questions you didn't cover!

Post them in the comments below and we will be glad to provide you with a response. :)
results.name: Costume Murder Mystery Party - Member Mix & Mingle

results.description:
And the saga continues....

Showtime is at 6:45, I will be at the theater by 5:45 and we will head in for seats at 6:15.  The movie is showing upstairs so we will gather by the tables near the windows at the top of the escalators.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  Tickets are on sale now on Fandango.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

results.description:
I am offering first choice to the 14 people who signed up and couldn't go because of bad weather.  If you cannot go on this date,  we'll open it to others.  If I  have missed anyone from the email list who was signed up to go on 8/21, please let me know and I'll put you in.  

 For intermediate to advanced photographers.  We have received permission to shoot at night in the sculpture park.  This is a fascinating place to light paint, with many creative possibilities.  The park ranges over 30 acres. 


Here is the link to the prior meetup in this location. The Orly Genger sculptures may be gone.


Because these are works of art there are some common sense restrictions: no touching, leaning on or sitting on the sculptures.  No steel wool spinning for obvious reasons.  The Sculpture Park and Museum must receive location credit on all published photography, and no images can be sold or reproduced  commercially without written permission from the deCordova museum.  This is essentially like the copyright on our work.  Know that for security purposes, the park is under video surveillance.

While the museum has waived the $300 event fee, we do have to pay a $14 entrance fee per person.  (Residents of Lincoln go for free)  You will need to pay when you sign up. For this reason, and because this is a limited meetup, please do not sign up unless you are sure you can go.  If you sign up and cannot go at the last minute, you'll be expected to pay the fee anyway.

 Bring all your flashlights and light painting gadgets.  Wide angle lenses will work well here.

Sunset is at 6:37, and we'll meet at 6:15 to orient ourselves first.  Meet in the parking lot.  Please be on time.  This is a four hour meetup, and will end at 10:15 PM.  My cell phone is[masked] 8820.
results.name: Light Painting at the de Cordova Sculpture Park

results.description:
This is one of my favorite restaurants and I thought that it might be nice to get a group together for a Tapas dinner. They offer a chef's tasting for $35 each and they bring out a huge variety of different dishes to try based on feedback from the group at the table. I have done this several times prior and have never left hungry and have gotten to try tons of things that I wouldn't usually get to try! Since figuring out a dinner bill with a large group is hard enough never mind with a ton of small plates, let's just keep the RSVPs to people who are OK with doing the chef's tasting menu. I figure that it will be $45 each with tax and tip included. ($35 x[masked]= $44.19 which includes 20% tip and 6.25% tax) We can see about paying for our drinks separately. If you RSVP please make every effort to make it as I'm sure that there will be folks on the wait list who'd also like to go.

Lastly, unfortunately I couldn't get a later RSVP even calling a month in advance!

results.description:
Hey everyone!

As many of you are no doubt aware, I'm a big fan of the (semi-)monstrous multiplayer games "Here I Stand" and its (semi-)sequel "Virgin Queen." As some of you are DEFINITELY already aware, the downside of playing these games is that they are pretty friggin' long to fit into a day's worth of play, so it's difficult to corral six interested folks for a session.

These games do, however, play very well via e-mail. So I'm proposing that we do exactly that. Specifically, I am proposing we play a game of Here I Stand via e-mail.

(Why Here I Stand and not Virgin Queen? Two reasons: 1) I have been a part of a couple of online HIS games, and I'm more comfortable using the online tools as a result, plus I am more familiar with what can go wrong, and 2) I haven't played HIS in quite a long time and I WANNA. So there.)

What you'll need: - You'll need access to a computer. (Presumably, you're in good shape on that score.)
- You'll need to be in a position where you can check your mail a couple of times per day, especially during the diplomacy phase. The more you're able to check, the faster the game will go!
- You'll need to download a free program called "CyberBoard" which will enable you to record your moves on a shared board. This is a Windows program, but Mac users should have no trouble running it under BootCamp or other Windows emulation-y software. Likewise Linux users should be able to run it under Wine. If you have a Mac or Linux box and the last two sentences sounded like gibberish, you may need to sit this one out, though I'm happy to assist to the extent I can.
- You'll need to sign up for a site called ACTS. This is also free, and it will enable us to keep track of your cards, victory points, etc.
- You'll need to be willing (at least in theory) to stick with a game that might take quite some time -- if you're the sort whose attention span flops if your online TTA game takes more than two weeks, this probably won't be the thing for you.

You do NOT need an encyclopedic understanding of the rules of Here I Stand (though it helps), or a similarly encyclopedic knowledge of the history of the 16th century Wars of Religion. This is going to be a learning game for some folks -- maybe lots of folks, so we're not going to put the pedal to the metal or be unforgiving of your little boo-boos. There's a lot to the game, but it's pretty amenable to learning as you go. If you have experience with games like Twilight Struggle, Successors, Labyrinth, Sword of Rome, etc., you'll have little trouble picking it up after a turn or two.

In order to get the game going ASAP, I'll be assigning the six powers to people after everyone's signed up. Here I Stand's sides are very asymmetrically powerful, so you'll be playing a very different game depending on which side you're playing. A quick rundown of the powers:

OTTOMANS: The Heathen Turks are uniquely uninterested in the religious struggle aspect of the game. Their goal is territory, power and loot. They are the only power that can engage in piracy in HIS. They are arguably the easiest side to play, so newcomers may want to play this side.

HAPSBURGS: This power controls The Empire (it's not necessary to specify which one; there's only one) and are incredibly powerful at the start of the game, but surrounded by powers who are out to get them. The Hapsburgs are arguably the trickiest power to play (in terms of rules they have to concern themselves with), however their strength is such that they can screw a couple things up and still do well. To succeed as the Hapsburgs, you need to explore and colonize the New World, make some gains in Europe and help keep the Protestant reformation in check.

FRANCE: The #2 power in Christendom, the French need to do a bit of everything to succeed. They're in a tough spot because their main rivals are the Hapsburgs who surround them on two sides, and they recently fought the Hundred Years' War with their neighbors to the North (England). So you might need to be a slick talker to avoid getting smooshed on all sides.

ENGLAND: The good news is that you're on an island, and few people are going to have the means of invading you en masse. The bad news is that you're on an island, and it's going to be tough to pick up victory points by invading over land. More (potentially) bad news? Your king is Henry VIII, and he doesn't have a male heir. You're going to need to fix that, which means a risky roll on the Pregnancy Table. Did I mention this is the sort of game that has a Pregnancy Table? Yeah.

PAPACY: As the Pope, you begin the game with a whole shed-load of victory points. The downside is that those points rapidly start to disappear as the Reformation sweeps Europe. And you have a pretty pathetic military, so you'll need to win the game through less bloody means. You can stanch the bleeding by burning books and winning theological debates -- but it's an uphill battle!

PROTESTANTS: At the start of the game, Martin Luther's just a monk with a grudge. But things blow up pretty quickly. Early on, you'll be concentrating on the Power of Ideas to get you ahead of the game. Later on, a pivotal event called the Shmalkaldic League will happen, and your collection of dissident German city-states will form into an independent country with an army of its own, and all the opportunities that gives you and the problems that causes...

If you're interested in signing up for the game, please leave a comment that states:

1) Your experience level with the game (played many times, played a couple times, played once, never played but played similar games, TOTAL N00B)
2) Any powers you'd especially LIKE to play or any powers you'd especially NOT like to play. If you don't state the latter, I will assume you're OK with whatever.

results.description:
Students will learn some basic elements of subtractive synthesis while shaping a variety of different sounds
-- Shaping basic analog drum sounds (kick, snare, open and closed hi hat) with the Amp Envelope.
-- Shaping different types of bass sounds (from warm and full to aggressive and noisy) by utilizing Oscillator 1 and 2 and the sub oscillator, introducing the filter and MOD envelope
-- Shaping lead sounds, introducing overdrive and distortion, also introducing OSC Filter MOD to show the wide variety of sounds possible.

Students will learn how to use these sounds with Ableton Live (or any DAW)
-- Recording audio and MIDI from Bass Station 2
-- Using Bass Station’s arpeggiator as a sequencer
-- Using Bass Station’s external input to utilize its filter on external sound sources.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bxL0AfLJiFI
results.name: Subtractive Synthesis and Sound Design with Novation Bass Station II [9/19]

results.description:
Cost of attendance is $25 and should be submitted via www.PayPal.com upon reservation to [masked] to secure a RSVP spot.

Please join us in the journey of indulging our taste buds into what was considered an elixir of the Gods in Pre-Hispanic times, and in post colonization evolved as what is now the Tequila. Originating from the Blue agave fields in Tequila, Jalisco in Mexico, the Tequila is an alcoholic drink produced with blue Weber agave. This agave plant is also known as weberi agave, weber agave, and agave tequilana (its scientific name).

Agaves from the Highlands produce sweet and frutal tequilas, while agaves from the Lowlands are more herbaceous in nature. We will have the opportunity to taste the liquor's aroma and taste, along with some Mexican food items aimed at helping your mouth embrace the flavors of the various Tequilas. It has a denomination of origin which limits production to 5 Mexican states: Jalisco, Nayarit, Tamaulipas, Michoacán and Guanajuato. The Consejo Regulador del Tequila (CRT for short) is the entity responsible for enforcing laws and regulating all tequila products.

A similar Mexican drink, mezcal, also uses agave. Mezcal can be produced anywhere in Mexico and is subject to different regulations than tequila. An aficionado will also recognize that mezcal has a different, usually harsher flavor. In short, all tequila is mezcal, but not all mezcal is Tequila.

The accompanying menu theme is Mexican so be prepared to try various food flavors. Some dish options contain nuts so PLEASE INDICATE ANY FOOD ALLERGIES.

*Tequilas will be provided, and there will be some Mezcal offerings as well.


DISCLAIMER: Please drink responsibly and make sure you either have a designated driver or a taxi pick you up. Tequila tasting should not exceed 2 ounces per hour and we highly encourage to chase it with water and/or food. Also note that although there will be various tequilas and mixing options Tequila tolerance varies per individual and by attending this event you are drinking and eating at the designated location at your own risk.
results.name: Tequila Indulgence...

LA Drummer Marla Leigh concert and workshops SEPT 19, 20

Export

Tell a friend

Share

Saturday, September 19, 2015

7:30 PM

Norwell, MA">

lubdub Studio Norwell MA

179 Norwell Ave, Norwell, MA 02061, Norwell, MA (map)

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Drumming in the Feminine: 
Discover the ONLY Women's Ancient Drumming Tradition" ♡

*Saturday, September 19
Concert with Marla Leigh with Slide Show presentation , 7:30pm

*Sunday, September 20 
Frame Drum Workshop, 2-5pm

~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *
*********************************************

Marla Leigh's East Coast Tour is starting here in Massachusetts on September 19 and 20. The concert is brought to you by Jan Hellew, Womyns Drumming Meetup, and BatucadaBelles.com, and Denise Rachael, thepianoworkshop.com, and Lubdubdrum.com. 

♡ Women were known as the first drummers!
As early as 5000 BCE, women were seen drumming in cultures worldwide playing a mystical instrument called the frame drum.

During ancient times, the frame drum was used for sacred ceremonies, rituals and rites of passages. Women’s spirituality, wisdom and sexuality were affirmed through rituals involving frame drumming.
. This special workshop immersion is designed to awaken and inspire the divine feminine through the ancient healing practices of frame drumming, traditional trance rhythms, chanting and meditation. 

Mental Health professional’s shows us that drumming reduces stress, anxiety and tension, and helps us experience being in resonance with the natural rhythms of life. Drumming enables a deep entrainment of the brain into states conductive to true healing. 

It is law of the universe that we actually accomplish and manifest way more by being in our grace, the essence of who we truly are. This is the place we attract what we need.

Experience the healing medicine, power and magic of frame drumming in a supportive community environment. 

Feel like you have NO drumming skills? 
Remember, we, as women, already know how to drum, as our ancestors practiced it thousands of years ago.

Join us for this extraordinary life changing experience

~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *
*********************************************
♡ WORKSHOP INCLUDES
*Frame Drum “Her-story” 
*Frame Drum Playing strokes
*Mind Body Integration
*Hand & foot coordination (great to sharpen your brain)
*Traditional rhythms from around the world.
*Rhythmic vocalizing (Solkattu)
*Drum & sing Shamanic Medicine Songs & Healing Chants *Improvise & Create your own rhythms
*Basic Music Fundamentals
*DruMeditation Healing Rituals
*Fun community group drum jams
*Sound Healing practices using Frame Drums and Voice
*Handouts

SEPTEMBER 20 |2-5pm
$46 Pre REg (Before September 12) - 
$65 Thereafter

***SPECIAL PACKAGE DISCOUNT***
BOTH CONCERT & WORKSHOP FOR ONLY $58

~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *~ * ~ * ~ *


“THE MEDICINE DRUM CONCERT ”

Come experience the incredibly healing power and medicine of music

Dance, trance, and meditate to the ancient sounds of the sacred. Marla’s concerts combine ecstatic world music with meditation, ritual, & movement.

In these special celebrations of music, Marla plays an array of sacred percussion instruments mixed with flutes, chants and ambient electronics. Marla uses a looping-pedal to create a one women band – to create sonically healing mystical textures, rhythms and melodies.

A featured instrument of this concert will be the frame drum, which is one of the worlds oldest archetype of drums; A drum that was traditionally played by women for sacred ceremonies in ancient times.

 During this concert for the first time she will be showing a slide show from the "When the women were drummers"  collected by the author the late Lanyne Redmond.  We are excited to have this important women history slide show debute here for our community!

For those of you not familiar with Layne I have attached this awesome video.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8oOnwYrsWE0

Marla Leigh Goldstein is a Los Angeles based professional Percussionist, Flautist, Composer and Educator, and one of the very  few female specialists in the ancient Mediterranean frame drum.  She is an internationally recognized teacher and performer, who has presented throughout the USA, Canada and Europe. 

The next day Sunday , September 20 Marla will be leading a drum workshop.  All drums are welcome and her drumming style can be used on djembe, dumbeks, and DunDuns.  

Marla Leigh has agreed to do  two events for us at a  discounted price for the women's drum community we have.  This is available  under  the  earlybird special until Sept 12, 20195.

Only one opportunity to see the full-length classic production of the world's most famous ballet:
Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake"!

Featuring Russia's brightest ballet stars!

Tickets start at only $18.


There’s a good reason why "Swan Lake" is so often called the ‘ballet of all ballets’. The combination of pure romanticism, the story about love and deception and Tchaikovsky’s world famous ballet music, all continue to reach new generations of audiences.

Russian Grand Ballet is founded by graduates from the Great Russian Ballet choreographic schools of Moscow, St. Petersburg and Kiev.

This is the full-length Ballet in 3 Acts with Two Intermissions.

results.description:
Only one opportunity to see the full-length classic production of the world's most famous ballet:
Tchaikovsky's "Swan Lake"!

Featuring Russia's brightest ballet stars!

Tickets start at only $18.


There’s a good reason why "Swan Lake" is so often called the ‘ballet of all ballets’. The combination of pure romanticism, the story about love and deception and Tchaikovsky’s world famous ballet music, all continue to reach new generations of audiences.

Russian Grand Ballet is founded by graduates from the Great Russian Ballet choreographic schools of Moscow, St. Petersburg and Kiev.

This is the full-length Ballet in 3 Acts with Two Intermissions.

THIS IS THE PLAN: You buy your own ticket. We will try to meet either before or after the Show. You can indicate on this site if you are looking to sit next to someone---I will let YOU arrange that.

Buy Tix from TheaterMania at : www.TheaterMania.com

results.description:
Grammy-winning singer and songwriter Gregory Porter is one of the most exciting male jazz vocalists on the scene today. Catch his performance with a great band and an exciting opening act, soulful singer-songwriter Avery Sunshine.

Porter has been called "the next great male jazz singer" by NPR Music, and the New York Times describes his songs as "strong and sometimes experimental yet serenely unacademic, and mightily good."

Check out his video, https://www.youtube.com/watch?feature=player_embedded&v=ZWUAKq-reLQ 

TICKETS:

Student Rush Tickets Now Available for $10.00! 
Just bring your Student ID to the Box Office.

Ticket are $37 and $47. Buy online or call Berklee Performance Center's Box office on[masked] (Monday - Saturday, 10:00a.m.-6:00p.m.)

BAG POLICY:

All bags are subject to search. Refusal of a bag search will result in denial of entry to the event.

DIRECTIONS AND PARKING:

By "T": Take the Green Line to the Hynes Convention Center stop. Exit left onto Massachusetts Avenue and cross Boylston Street. The Berklee Performance Center is about 30 yards from the corner. Consult the MBTA Web site for bus routes and schedules.

From points west: Take the Massachusetts Turnpike (Interstate 90) east to exit 22 (Prudential Center exit), which begins in a tunnel. When you reach this exit, bear left onto street level and stay left onto Huntington Avenue. Merge into the right lane and turn right at the third traffic light onto Massachusetts Avenue. The Berklee Performance Center is on your right, just past the third light.

From points due south: Take Route 93 north (Southeast Expressway) to the Massachusetts Avenue/Roxbury exit (a right-lane exit). Turn right onto Massachusetts Avenue at the traffic light. Continue on Massachusetts Avenue. The Berklee Performance Center is on your right, at the intersection of Mass Ave. and Boylston Street.

From points due north: Take Route 93 south or Route 1 south. These roads converge at Boston's central artery. Follow the signs for Storrow Drive heading west and stay in the center lane. Take the Fenway exit and get into the left lane. Make a hard left onto Boylston Street and continue to the Massachusetts Avenue intersection. Turn right. The Berklee Performance Center is on the left, about 30 yards from the corner.

Parking

Limited metered parking is available on the streets surrounding the Berklee Performance Center and Berklee College of Music.

Parking is also available at nearby parking garages:

The Hynes Auditorium Garage, located on 50 Dalton Street next to Bukowski's Tavern. Maximum rate for evening parking (4 p.m.-5 a.m.) is $15.00. The Berklee Performance Center offers a $5 discount with validation. Weekdays before 4 p.m. patrons will receive a discount of $2.50 OFF the first 1/2 hour and $2.50 off the second 1/2 hour (or $5 off the first hour). To receive discounts and promotional rates patrons must present concert ticket and parking ticket for validation at the Berklee Performance Center box office during business hours on event day. Tickets must be validated to receive any eligible discounts. Visit pilgrimparking.com for more information.The Prudential Center Garage on Boylston Street, just past the Hynes Convention Center. The garage may offer a discount if you present your Berklee ticket stub to the garage attendant. For more information or directions, call the garage office at[masked] or visit their website at prudentialcenter.com.The First Church of Christian Science Garage, located below the reflection pool, offers evening rates of $12 for up to two hours before and after each event. Evening rates during Symphony Hall events and weekends are $20. Click here for more information.The Haviland Street Garage, directly across from the BPC (behind Starbucks) on 5 Haviland Street and 1085 Boylston Street. <a>patparking.com</a>The Back Bay Hilton, located on Dalton Street. Heading north on Massachusetts Avenue, take a right onto Boylston Street and then another right at the first light, just before the Hynes Convention Center.Danker & Donohue Garage, located at 341 Newbury Street. Call[masked] for current rates and information.Central Parking Jazz, located at 1087 Boylston Street. Call[masked] for current rates and information.Sheraton Boston Hotel Parking Garage, located at 39 Dalton Street

The aforementioned businesses are listed as a courtesy to our patrons. The Berklee Performance Center and Berklee College of Music are not affiliated with these garages and cannot be held responsible for any lost, stolen or damaged items.

Accessible Parking Locations

Accessible parking spaces are available at all of the garages/lots listed. Accessible street parking spaces do exist in the Back Bay but are extremely limited. At present, eight spaces exist near the theater and are designated by street signs that mark the area reserved for accessible parking. A Disabled Placard may be used in any parking space designated as HP parking. Other parking ordinances may be in effect. All designated parking rules should be obeyed. Massachusetts law allows vehicles with proper Disabled Parking authority to disregard most - but not all - public meter fees. Note, however, Massachusetts Port Authority does not exempt meter fees for Disabled Parking. Do not park in a cross-hatch area (Zebra Stripe) adjacent to an HP space. This area is reserved for van ramp access.

Two spaces exist on Belvedere Street, near Massachusetts Avenue.One space exists on Haviland Street, near the intersection of Hemenway Street.Two more exist in front of 15 Hemenway Street.One space exists where St. Cecilia Street intersects with Boylston Street.Two spaces exist where Massachusetts Avenue intersects with Boylston Street, next to the old bank building.

All of these space are conveniently located within a short distance from the Berklee Performance Center. Please obey all posted signs. Due to street cleaning, public events, snow emergencies or construction, availability and accessibility status of any given space is subject to change without notice.

results.description:
The Cape Ann Contra Dance September Soiree will be held this Saturday, September 19 at the Magnolia Library Community Center, 1 Lexington Street, Magnolia, MA.

The dancing starts at 8:00 PM. No experience is necessary, nor do you need to bring a partner All dances are taught. Dancers of all ages are welcome; attendees range from eight years to 80 plus years!

Live music and dance instruction are provided by the Cape Ann Contra Dance House Band.

Sit-in musicians are welcome. Please visit http://www.manystrings6.com/dance/dance5.html
for more information

There is a requested donation of $10 per dancer/sit-ins, dancers/sit-ins younger than 16 are free.

This event is supported in part by a grant from the Gloucester Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency. The Cape Ann Contra Dances are organized and produced by Folk Life Studio.

Drinking water is available. Please bring water bottles to reduce the use of paper cups. Other non-alcoholic drinks and finger food snacks are welcomed to share during the break.

For more information, contact [masked].
Find us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/events/711884165623360/
results.name: Cape Ann Contra Dance September Soiree

results.description:
Sorry Will Smith, Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy, THE MENDOZA LINE, brings the heat, FOR REAL
This and every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you a different lineup stacked with the biggest, baddest, and bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess the funk what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS! With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful and quality laughs Featuring the comedic talents of:

Brett Hiker (High Plains Comedy Festival)

Rohan Padye (San Diego Comedy Festival)

Andrew Mayer (debut album "Nonsense" comes out this week)

Kate Procyshyn (Arch City Comedy Festival)

Ryan Donahue (Just For Laughs Festival)

Casey Malone (Fine Line Comedy)

SPECIAL GUEST HOST Adam Langlois (The Lego Movie)

AND MORE!

Buy your tix now to guarantee a seat as spaces are limited. We don't want to turn you away again, Shannon!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114

results.description:
Let's all go and see Cooties, the new horror-comedy starring Elijah Wood (also producer), at the Brattle in Harvard Square. 

I recommend people purchase tickets in advanced to prevent the show from selling out. Tickets can be purchased here.

Film Description:

(2014) dir Jonathan Millott, Cary Murnion w/Elijah Wood, Rainn Wilson, Alison Pill, Jack McBrayer, Leigh Whannell, Nasim Pedrad, Ian Brennn, Jorge Garcia [88 min; DCP]

When frustrated NYC writer Clint (Wood) returns to his smallhometown to try and finish (or maybe start) his novel, he takes a job as a substitute teacher at his old elementary school. His reunion with childhoodcrush Lucy (Pill) – also a teacher at the school – is interrupted by an outbreak of mutant bird flu that turns the school’s students into homicidal maniacs. With the safety of the town – and maybe the world – at stake, a brave band of misfit teachers, including Lucy’s erstwhile fiancé Wade (Wilson), must make a stand against the bloodthirsty tykes.

Gloriously over-the-top, COOTIES is a bloody and hilarious horror-comedy that finally allows both teachers and kids the opportunity to do what they’ve always wanted to: tear each other to shreds.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UdvYU1JeykM

Cross-posted: https://www.facebook.com/events/410019192531389/

results.description:
Organizer: Steve Blum  @[masked]


=========================

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event. Sometimes the questions won't show up if you use a phone or tablet to RSVP so use a computer. 

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself as well as others at risk so consider this before you decide to participate. Contact me if you have any questions. 

=========================

What We're Doing...

The plan is to climb four of the NH 52 WAV - Mts. Crawford, Stairs, Resolution and Parker.


We will  meet at the Mt. Langdon Trailhead in Bartlett, NH, where the hike will end and we will spot cars here. We will then drive west on Rt. 302 to the Davis Trailhead, about 5 miles away to begin the hike up Mt. Crawford. We will continue on the Davis Path to Stairs Mountain.  We will return to the Mt. Parker Trail over Mt. Resolution to Mt. Parker. From Mt. Parker, we will descend to River St in Bartlett by way of the Mt. Parker Trail and the Langdon Trail.


Since you are ultimately responsible for your own safety you will need to become self-reliant by learning about the route and potential hazards. Use this link for more information about the summits and trails:

Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.29819&lat=44.12339#.VeNGu5d2GSo

Guests are not permitted - all participants must be members of the group.


Dogs are permitted with advanced notice - be sure to bring a leash in case you need to use it.

Trip Summary...

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 13 miles and climb about 4275 feet. It should take an average hiker about 8 1/2 hours to complete this trip. This event is considered to be ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

What to Bring...

Use this link for a list of items needed for an autumn day hike:


• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

Directions...


We will meet in the parking lot at the trailhead for the LangdonTrail which is located at the end of River St. in Bartlett, NH. Since this is where we will finish, we will then drive to the Davis Path Trailhead. According to Google Maps this meeting spot is 175 miles from Boston and it should take about 2 hours and 50 minutes to drive there.

Use this link for customizable driving directions:

https://www.google.com/maps/dir/Boston,+MA/Cobb+Farm+Rd+%26+Yates+Farm+Rd+%26+River+St,+Glen,+NH+03838/@43.3488015,-72.7445973,8z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m13!4m12!1m5!1m1!1s0x89e3652d0d3d311b:0x787cbf240162e8a0!2m2!1d-71.0588801!2d42.3600825!1m5!1m1!1s0x4cb39c2b13b9669d:0x5a7d785cad0731d8!2m2!1d-71.285915!2d44.084218

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride. If you do share a ride be sure to share the expenses (gas and tolls).

Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer...

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.
results.name: Crawford to Parker: 52WAVx4 ADVANCED

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Meet in front of Sam Adams statue next to Faneuil Hall at 7:30 AM

Under the direction of Mayor Martin J. Walsh, Boston Bikes is a City of Boston program to encourage citizens and visitors to use bicycles for fun, exercise, and transportation.  Our goal is to make Boston a vibrant and healthy city that benefits all its citizens. By creating safe and inviting conditions for all residents and visitors, we seek to make our home into a world-class bicycling city. Join us this year for one of the nation's largest cycling celebrations, including the 7th annual TD Bank Mayor's Cup Criterium and 11th annual Hub on Wheels city-wide ride.

Hub On Wheels (HOW) was founded in 2005 with three goals: create an important civic event, showcase Boston's neighborhoods and parks, and raise money for important causes. Each year the ride brings together participants, hundreds of volunteers, and numerous local businesses in celebration of Boston and bicycling. With routes looping through Downtown, the Back Bay, Jamaica Plain, Roslindale, Hyde Park, Mattapan, Dorchester, and South Boston, it presents a truly unique way to see our great city. Hub On Wheels is Boston's largest city-sponsored sporting event.

Join ECTA for a guided bike tour of the Rail Trail through Topsfield, Wenham and Danvers!  We will begin at Town Hall in Topsfield and ride to Danvers Center, where our friends from Seaside Cycle will meet us with refreshments.  We'll stop for along the way to see the Swamp Walk and the Wenham Canal. This is a great chance to discover a fantastic and safe multi-use path you never knew was there.

The ride is about 14 miles round trip, on hard packed surface over relatively flat terrain.  Total trip should take a couple of hours.  Helmets required.  Hybrid or mountain bikes are recommended, though the surfacing on most of the trail is ok for a road bike.  

For more information about this ride, please email us.

 
This event is part of the Trails & Sails event series sponsored by Essex National Heritage.

REGISTER FOR THIS EVENT AT:  http://ecta27.camp7.org/event-2017499

results.description:
I apologize for changing the nature and location of this month's meetup, but I found out that Smokak Farms is still open for peach picking, and I couldn't resist! My entire family loves peaches, and if you do as well, and also want to hang out with some awesome Japanese speaking families, please join us! Peach picking at Smolak Farms is extremely reasonable at $1.99/lb. It would be nice if you can join us at the Harvest Festival after the picking, since there are lots of activities for little children. I think the "All About Animals" activity ($15 per child) is most appropriate for this group, which includes feeding and petting the farm animals, pony ride, hay ride, duck races, hay pyramid, corn crib, face painting, and the use of the playground. Hayride for adults is $4/adult, and lasts 20 minutes. Be sure to bring snacks and lunch, if you don't want just apple cider donuts and muffins. I have the following schedule on my mind, but we'll tweak it as we go, since nothing really happens on schedule with little ones!

10:00am :            Arrival. Meet at the main entrance. 

10:15-10:45am:  Peach picking. Nectarines and plums are also available!

11:00am:              Snack time. May turn into lunch if kids are hungry.

11:15am-whenever you have to leave: All About Animals Harvest Festival. I'm thinking we'll do the farm animals first, and once food has settled in our stomachs, catch a hayride at the ice cream stand. 

For more info, check out their website at http://www.smolakfarms.com/harvest-festivals

It'll probably be crowded, but we'll try and stick with the group. If you are running late, or get lost, my number is[masked]-3960. I look forward to reconnecting with old friends and meeting new friends. It'll be fun! 

Cheers,

Michi

results.description:
Come on out and join the Inline Club of Boston for our weekly Sunday Morning City Skate!

Every Sunday morning May through September (weather permitting) we meet up at JFK Park in Cambridge for a 6 to 8 mile skate through the streets of Cambridge, Somerville and parts of Boston. Destinations vary widely and may include city neighborhoods, City Squares such as Harvard and Kendall, Harvard and MIT campuses and bike paths on both sides of the river.

This is designed as an entry level city skate so there are some points prospective participants should keep in mind. 

We do skate in the streets so you will need to be comfortable on your skates in light city traffic. We do try to keep to the more quiet roads but traffic is never completely predictable.

You should have good stopping skills. The city does present a wide variety of obstacles and the ability to control your speed and stop is important.

It is important that you are comfortable negotiating minor road obstacles such as curbs, sewer grates, sand or dirt and substandard pavement.

We do periodically go down small hills.

We recommend that you wear all protective gear. Most of the things out here are pretty hard!

Of course we do our best to minimize these issues but it is never possible to miss them all.

If this sounds like something for you and you have some more questions or need more info please feel free to contact Neil Wetzler at [masked] and we will respond as quickly as possible.

We meet up at JFK park around 10 and depart at 10:30. As stated, the skate is generally 6 to 8 miles in length and will last between an hour and fifteen minutes and an hour an a half. Most Sundays we gather afterwards for coffee and treats or lunch and to talk about our skating adventures. The skate is always announced Saturday morning on the ICB mailing list, Facebook page and Meetup page.

Even if you don’t feel you are up to this skate yet please feel free to come and meet the group any Sunday morning. If this is your first Sunday Skate please introduce yourself to the skate leader and other skaters. We were all new to this once and will be very happy to welcome you to the skate. Even if you’re not up to skating with us quite yet please feel free to come by and meet the group.

We also run a Midweek on the Minuteman skate that may be more to your liking. You can meet some of the group and develop the skills that will get you out on a Sunday!

We hope to meet you soon!

Getting to JFK Park: Take the T (Red Line) to Harvard Square, or if driving, you can park on most streets since Cambridge’s resident-only parking restriction is lifted on Sundays. We normally park on Memorial Drive (just to the West of JFK park) or Mt. Auburn St, and walk/skate over to the park.

Check out the skills necessary for this event in our Skate Skills page.

Don’t forget to sign up for our mailing list to receive updates about this and other ICB events!
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at JFK Park in Cambridge by the fountain, about 100 yards from the intersection

What to expect: This monthly meeting typically begins with an introduction all around for the benefit of any first-time attendees, and discussion of any announcements, upcoming events, etc. We then move on to a topic of interest to atheists (usually) chosen beforehand. Sometimes participants bring print-outs of articles, research, or books to share on the topic, and sometimes people just come with a story or opinion to share.

We loosely moderate the topical discussion to give everyone a chance to participate. Then the conversation often flows onto other related subjects, sometimes in smaller conversation groups around the table.

If you have any ideas for meeting topics, please let any of the co-organizers know. We can also add announcements or "mini-topics" on the agenda if there's anything you'd like to share with the group.

results.description:
Join us at the nation's largest local & sustainable food hub. Boston Local Food Festival is a free outdoor festival that showcases farmers, local restaurants, food trucks, specialty food producers, fisher folks, and organizations focusing on healthy food and fitness from New England. The festival also features lively chef & DIY demos, a seafood throwdown competition, diverse music and performances, family fun zone and more.

-Learn about the benefits of sustainably grown and produced food
-Shop the market
-Eat delicious local food
-Participate in fun, educational activities and exhibits
-Engage with top local chefs
-Enjoy local music

Getting There

Directions

The 5th Boston Local Food Festival will be held on The Rose Kennedy Greenway again this year.  The Festival spans just over 3 blocks of the Rose Kennedy Greenway, starting at State Street and Atlantic Ave, and continuing down the greenway just past High Street and Atlantic Ave. It is just a short walk from Downtown Boston, and is conveniently located near South Station, Faneuil Hall, and The Aquarium.

The festival will take place in the Wharf District and American Heritage parks. We strongly encourage festival-goers to use alternative transportation, such as public transportation, walking, biking, or by taking a water taxi, to attend the event, instead of driving.

Bike to the Festival!

Hubway is metro-Boston’s bike sharing system providing more than 1,300 bikes at 140 stations throughout Boston, Brookline, Cambridge, and Somerville.  Grab a bike near your home, office, or school and pedal your way to the next lunch meeting, class, errand, or shopping trip, or to visit friends and family.  There are multiple Hubway stations close to the festival:

Aquarium Station at 200 Atlantic AvenueMilk Street at India StreetRowes Wharf at Atlantic AvenueFaneuil Hall at Union Street & North StreetMayor J. Martin Walsh Station at 28 State StreetPost Office SquareLewis Wharf at Atlantic Avenue

Take the T to the Festival!

Blue Line to Aquarium/Faneuil Hall
Red Line to South Station
Green Line to Haymarket or North Station
Orange Line to Downtown Crossing
Commuter Rail to South Station or North Station

These are last years vvvv , the new ones aren't out at the time of posting.

One of the best ways to improve your own photography is  to look at the work of others. Not just photographs, put paintings as well. You can learn lots about composition, color, light, texture, line and all the other topics I cover in our classes by taking time to see these elements in art.  Great news! You can see it all at Open Studios in the South End when over 200 artists open their doors to the public.(including me)

Sunday Sept. 20th  You are invited to come to my studio at the Boston Center for the Arts 551 Tremont near the Beehive Resturant and join our meetup group for a tour of artists studios. I am on the 4th floor come on up.


I will provide a map and specific visual qualities to look for so you can get inspired. Bring your camera and a notebook. You will meet wonderful, interesting artists, see some fantastic art and have fun with other members of our group. 

RSVP Now. Everyone who comes to my studio to start the tour will be eligible to win a spot in a future class tuition free!  See you there! 

Suzanne

Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
Join us on court this Sunday at 11 a.m. for the start of this spring season's Beginner Level Group Tennis Clinics conducted by highly experience tennis professionals.


This weekly (every Sunday) series of group clinics is a 6-session, 9 hour (each session runs 90 minutes) series of clinics designed for beginner level tennis players.

The fundamentals of tennis will be covered throughout the series in a format that will utilize precise tennis drills and clear description of fundamentally correct tennis technique to reinforce these tennis essentials with each participating player.

Each 90-minute session in the series will include: warm-up exercises; dynamic stretching; cardio drills; skill-building tennis drills; description and demonstration of fundamentally sound tennis strokes.

Each participant will get to hit many balls during drills under the watchful eye of the supervising tennis pro.

We have priced this series of clinics at the handsomely discounted, cost-friendly rate of just $135. That averages a very low $15/hr/player.

Learn the game of tennis or improve your beginner level strokes. In these clinics, you'll do just that and, at the same time, increase your enjoyment of tennis.

Make this the year you take your tennis game to the next level!

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting. ------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

We will be doing a hike, some open field play, and swimming for those dogs so inclined. All ages and breeds of dogs are invited and can easily participate. Please use the address above to meet us: 900 Main Street, Stoneham, MA and here is a map of the full Reservation:

On a personal note this will be my last event for approximately 5 weeks due to major back surgery the 2nd week of September. I  hope many of you can join. 


We have several other events upcoming including a confirmed Fundraiser for the Meetup Group and larger nonprofit that benefits many members of the MG hosted by The Pour House and a benefit with the Liberty Hotel in junction with their Yappie Hour date to be announced with multiple sponsors already on-board and seeking additional sponsors to step forward for some major initiatives in the Fall.

Lastly, and most importantly, I would like to recognize BOSTON DOGS ORGANIZATION NONPROFIT TOOK ON AMAZON.COM AND WON, the NPO first recognized and spearheaded a campaign 25 counties and all six populatedcontinents and won recently by Boston Dogs Organization nonprofit to stop Amazon's selling of dogs online via unvetted breeders with the help of a BDO Facebook advocates and change.org campaign in which you can still sign #BanDogsOnAmazon. Thank you Mary Schwager for publishing our victory here and not ironically a New York Times piece two days later detailing Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos' treatment of his own worker never-mind dogs. 


Finally, we have had some issues this summer with attendance at Meetups. Please come if you RSVP, please let us know 48 hours as a courtesy is you cannot come and have already RSVPed.

Thank you Bostonian Dog Lovers! Woof!

YOUR EXCLUSIVE 2015 RED SOX NATIVES GAME VIEWING EVENT will be hosted by the Red Sox Natives!

Brady is free and leading the Patriots once again!

Please join us at the Tony C's Sports Bar and Grille at Assembly Square in Somerville for the Game Viewing on Sunday, September 20. The Patriots will play at the Buffalo Bills.

 Arrive early at 12:00pm to get a good seat and for some pre-game socializing. 

 Game Time is 1:00pm.

Wear your Patriots gear.

Several VOLUNTEER Natives led by Andrea and friends.... will arrive early and reserve a table/section. Expect a  BIG crowd. We STRONGLY advise you arrive early to watch the 1:00pm  game  rather than late to avoid any lines as Tony C's is HOT!   Capacity is 400 people inside and a wild experience. 

Tony C's has 11,000 Square feet of space, has a capacity of nearly 500 (including patio), has over 90 HD Big Screen TVs and a JUMBOTRON along with the highest quality audio system!

Please make sure to maintain your own bar and food tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. If you are seated at a group table you may be part of a group bill. Please communicate with your servers in advance for an individual bill. Servers may take credit cards. 

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill is a sports themed restaurant named to honor Red Sox legend and Massachusetts Native Tony Conigliaro. It combines a fresh, house-made menu of American comfort food and the highest quality HD audiovisual system available. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Due to the increase in participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• To be sure there is enough seating, feel free to bring your own folding chair. 

• Due to some food allergy-prone dogs, please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.

results.description:
Owen's whirlwind tour of the complex plane touched on so many things, among them generating functions, which is a topic that fascinates me.  Owen mentioned the great Philippe Flajolet, who, along with his pal Robert Sedgewick, literally wrote the book on this stuff.  Specifically, how to use generating functions to solve counting problems, for example, "How many  rooted binary trees are there with n nodes?"  the answer is called the Catalan number Cn and the fact that this is asymptotic to 4^n/sqrt(pi*n^3) is important for computer algorithms employing binary trees. 

Amazingly (to me, anyway) we often find generating functions (power series) that blow up at some finite value due to a singularity or pole.  If we stay on the real line, we face an arduous challenge to extract the counting information from the generating function, but if we analytically continue the function to the complex plane, we find that the poles in fact provide the key to deriving extremely accurate information about the enumeration of the class of structures under consideration, with almost no work at all!

Links:

Analytic continuation

Analytic combinatorics

Catalan numbers

The Flajolet & Sedgewick book (11 MB)

******************************************************

A NOTE ON THE LOCATION: For first-timers, getting into the building can be a bit tricky. See this page for a map and explanation.
results.name: Analytic Combinatorics, Generating Functions, Complex Magic. Or, How to count

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/
