results.description:
Why are New Englanders so rude" is the number one ranked searched term related to the people in our region. This common misconception, I believe, is due to a culture that has taught us to be efficient with our own time and to respect others. The flip side to this efficiency is commonly seen at many networking events. Plain and simple: most New Englanders don't know how to network. They are too polite to waste someone else's time, and often wait for someone to walk up to them. Learn how to easily become the person that everyone wants to talk to, and the financial and personal benefits that come with it. Event Topic: Networking For New Englanders: Make a Friend & Some Money Too


At our weekly marketing meeting, Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development, will discuss:

1. What networking is(and what it is not)
2. Why you always need to network
3. How to make networking completely comfortable
4. Determining where you should network and how to find the events

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has helped his team to acquire over 24 properties in the past 6 months including both fix and flip and buy and hold transactions.
results.name: Networking For New Englanders: Make a Friend & Some Money Too

results.description:
Folks, you are the core of the IoT cluster in Eastern MA and the heart of the IoT Hub that is Boston.


Industrial Internet Consortium reached out to ask if we would make you all aware of their meeting coming up this week.


Wednesday. September 23. 0800. FREE. Bring your critical listening, sharp analytics, and clear comms to help them learn from you what is really happening in IoT markets.


Following is from our friend Kathy Walsh ...


>>> <<<

The Internet has revolutionized our communications, our core competencies and our business processes. The next wave of the Internet is connecting machines and devices together into functioning, intelligent systems. This Internet of things, machines, computers and people - the Industrial Internet - will work together with unprecedented speed, scale and capabilities and produce transformational business outcomes. Every industry will be affected, such as:

·  Healthcare providers integrating clinical systems and patient monitoring devices for better quality of care

·  Transportation companies advancing highway and airway safety and efficiency with better monitoring and control

·  Energy companies adopting remote monitoring and maintenance of their infrastructure for higher performance and control

Companies deploying Industrial Internet solutions are setting the foundations for the future. Those who are not, risk being left behind.

On the morning of September 23rd, the Industrial Internet Consortium is hosting an Industrial Internet Forum at the Hyatt Regency in Cambridge, Massachusetts.  This complimentary event features Industrial Internet Consortium Executive Director Richard Soley, ARC Analyst Greg Gorbach and others who will discuss the vision, technical challenges, and real-world applications of the Industrial Internet.  Specific topics include:

·  Interoperability Requirements for the Industrial Internet of Things

·  The Convergence of OT & IT

·  Best Practices for Securing an Industrial IoT System

·  Business Transformation 

This event is a great opportunity for you to learn more about the Industrial Internet. Click here for the list of speakers, full agenda and registration. The event is free but registration is required.

Feel free to contact me if you have any questions. I hope you will consider coming to the event. Please feel free to pass the word around to anyone you think may be interested.

Thanks,
results.name: Another RIDE-ALONG: Industrial Internet Consortium. Wed AM. Hyatt Cambridge.

results.description:
If you’re looking for a meaningful, progressive and creative way to celebrate Jewish culture, history, and identity --

If you are, among other things, a humanist, atheist, agnostic, skeptic, secular, unaffiliated, a “none,” or any other nonreligious descriptive -- You’re invited to the first-ever high holiday celebrations at the Humanist Hub!

The Jewish high holidays are traditionally a time to reflect on the past year and set intentions for the coming one. As Jewish humanists, we recognize the value of putting aside time each year to engage in this process, but also demand that holiday rituals be updated to fit our nontheistic beliefs. With this year's services at the Hub, we are attempting to create a communal experience that reflects the importance of our Jewish cultural roots while also expressing our humanistic philosophy of life. We’re also working to create a secular alternative to the traditional holiday liturgy that represents a beautiful work of art in its own right, and will highlight the holidays' traditional themes through poetry, debate, meditation, discussion, and song. We have deliberately included several Hebrew selections, given Hebrew’s importance to the Jewish people and its role in the secular liturgy that is found in modern Israeli music and poetry. There's a little something for everyone, we hope. And at the end of the holidays, we'll seek your feedback about which rituals you liked (or didn't!) to incorporate into our plans for next year. We hope you'll join us for our celebration of the Jewish new year and the circle of life.

TICKETS REQUIRED. Get them and learn more here:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/new-traditions-for-the-jewish-new-year-the-high-holidays-as-secular-celebrations-tickets-18300698883

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Join us for a free screening and discussion with Hanan Harchol, as part of our Humanist High Holidays celebration.

Hanan Harchol is a multimedia artist, born in Israel, who moved to the US as a child. Harchol creates paintings, drawings, animations, videos, and multimedia installations that explore the human condition through family narratives. Harchol has gained worldwide attention for his animated series, “Jewish Food For Thought,” representing his personal journey in a complicated relationship with Judaism, by combining thousands of years of Jewish wisdom on topics such as apology, forgiveness, gratitude, love, fear, humility, and others, with artmaking (i.e., animations of his Israeli nuclear physicist father and himself, having arguments).
results.name: Yom Kippur Film Screening and Discussion

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others!

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share'
buttons
http://www.yelp.com/events/boston-volunteering-for-2-bag-of-produce-in-mission-hill-each-wednesday-afternoon-from-4-6-pm-at-tobin-community-center

TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas

Vegan Cooking Classes or  
Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food
(using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 


What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag? Portion Control Bake...Don't Fry! Roasted Veggie Stackers No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream Avocados!!! Salad with Chipotle Hummus Simple Cilantro Chutney More $2 bags of Produce! Drink your greens!

From Chinese Progressive Association and the Asian American Resource Workshop:


"R Visions for Chinatown is a one-week series of temporary art interventions in Boston's Chinatown highlighting issues and struggles of the Chinese community. R Visions features local artists' work with an emphasis on interactive art and engaging the public.

This fall, R Visions for Chinatown aims to highlight the affordable housing crisis, particularly focusing on the displacement of residents from Chinatown's historic row houses and calling for their right to remain in the community."


As part of "R Visions for Chinatown," we'll participate in the R Visions Walking Tour and Action.  More details to come.  Also, to find out what else is happening as part of their larger project, go to the Facebook page for the event.
results.name: Learn about and protest Chinatown's affordable housing crisis

results.description:
If you want to buy a house, you might make it easy on yourself by buying the first available house you find. You might instead want to get the very best deal by evaluating every single detail of every house for sale, and then carefully considering your own preferences in order to weight the features of each house. Is it worth it? How valuable is all of that information?

We're going to talk about making decisions by doing simple calculations, and in particular dealing with the question of whether gathering additional information to improve your calculation is worthwhile.

Our current schedule is
5:30-6pm Welcome and discuss progress from last week
6-7:00pm Focused discussion and work on our topic. In addition to talking about theory, we really want to make actual progress on real problems.
7-7:30pm Conclusion and set individual goals for next meeting
7:30-... Mingle and leave whenever

Please bring something to write with and on.
results.name: Value of Information

results.description:
Slavish Shore: The Odyssey of Richard Henry Dana, Jr. 

Registration is required ($20). Event link and registration HERE (with one scroll-down and two clicks - no charge for Fellows and Members). 

Note: Two Years Before the Mast is the first book to be added to The CMF Recommended Reading List, which can be found HERE. 


:: :: ::

Wednesday, September 23rd, 6pm - Pre-talk reception at 5:30

Massachusetts Historical Society - 1154 Boylston Street, Boston

:: :: ::

Jeffery Amestoy, Harvard Kennedy School

In 1834, Richard Henry Dana Jr. sailed to California as a common seaman while taking a convalescence break from Harvard. 

His account of the voyage, Two Years Before the Mast, quickly became an American classic. But literary acclaim could not erase the young lawyer’s memory of the brutal floggings he had witnessed aboard ship or undermine the vow he had made to combat injustice. In Slavish Shore, Jeffrey Amestoy tells the story of Dana’s unflagging determination to keep that vow in the face of nineteenth-century America’s most exclusive establishment: the Boston society in which he had been born and bred. Dana’s extraordinary advocacy put him at the center of some of the most consequential cases in American history: defending fugitive slave Anthony Burns, justifying President Lincoln’s war powers before the Supreme Court, and prosecuting Confederate president Jefferson Davis for treason. Yet Dana’s own promising political career remained unfulfilled as he struggled to reconcile his rigorous conscience with his restless spirit in public controversy and private life. 

Jeffrey Amestoy was the 38th Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of Vermont. He was elected Attorney General of Vermont in 1984 and was re-elected six times. In five of those elections he was the nominee of the Republican and Democratic parties. In 1997 he was appointed to the Supreme Court by Governor Howard Dean. In 1999 Amestoy was author of the Vermont Supreme Court's opinion in Baker v. State which held that same-sex couples were constitutionally entitled to the rights and benefits of marriage.
results.name: Richard Henry Dana

results.description:
Merchants of Boston, including Boston Athenæum benefactors James and Thomas Handasyd Perkins, participated eagerly and built fortunes in the 19th-century China Trade. The Perkins brothers--whose portraits grace the Athenæum’s first-floor Henry Long Room and Deborah Hill Bornheimer Room--traded in tea, coffee, silk, and sugar on three continents and navigated markets in war and peace. They also profited from illicit opium trade between Turkey and China. Amitav Ghosh’s novels in the Ibis Trilogy offer a fictionalized glimpse of the world in which the Perkins brothers operated.

This program is offered in anticipation of the Athenæum's India Heritage and Literary Tour in January 2016.

With all the verve of the first two novels in the trilogy, Flood of Fire completes Ghosh’s unprecedented re-envisioning of the nineteenth century war on drugs. With remarkable historic vision and a vibrant cast of characters, Ghosh brings the Opium Wars to bear on the contemporary moment with the storytelling that has charmed  readers around the world.

Amitav Ghosh is the internationally bestselling author of Sea of Poppies (shortlisted for the Man Booker Prize) and River of Smoke, the first two novels in the Ibis Trilogy, of which Flood of Fire is the final installment. He has written ten other novels and works of nonfiction, including three essay collections. A frequent contributor to The New Yorker, The New Republic, The New York Times, and others, his work has been translated into more than twenty languages.

FREE


Registration for this event will begin on September 9 at 9:00 a.m.

To register, click here follow the registration button on the right.
results.how_to_find_us: Those attending should meet outside the main door at 5:45
results.name: Flood of Fire: Book Talk about the Opium Wars

results.description:
NOTE: To officially RSVP for this event, please do so on the official Boston VR event listing here: http://www.meetup.com/Boston-Virtual-Reality/events/223143861/


We're going on tour! Join us in one of nine cities across the globe for a crash course on integrating 3D motion control and interaction design into VR, desktop, and beyond.

Sign up for the 3D Jam

Please register on the Boston VR meetup page. From the Boston VR meetup page:

This is going to be a very special meetup because it coincides with the Unite conference. In addition to our main presentations from Meta and Leap we'll have a lot of other new demos to experience! You can find the full list at the bottom of the page. 

Meta builds the first wearable augmented reality computer and platform which lets you create, share, and collaborate with digital objects in the real world. Developers have flocked to Meta’s AR hardware and software platform to create professional and gaming applications for numerous industries. Learn more at getameta.com. 

Join us for a two day workshop and cocktail party in Boston. Learn Unity 3D and build a Meta app in just two days. Beginners welcome! Use the code bosvrmeetup for an extra 15% off and take advantage of early bird pricing through August 23: metaworkshopboston.eventbrite.com

Company bio: 
Leap Motion technology brings dynamic 3D hand input into virtual reality, augmented reality, Mac and PC, allowing developers to bring natural hand input into next gen digital environments. 

Speaker's Bio:

results.description:
Join us for a discussion on "How to Build an Online Store."


Learning how to build an online store from scratch can be a daunting task.  We know! - We've been there before. 

This Meetup will cover setting up your first online store, no matter where you are in the product development process - from a simple landing page to a website which accepts pre-orders, to finally, a fully functioning eCommerce site.

___________________________________________________


This Meetup will cover:

• How to build an online store from scratch - without any coding experience!

• Understanding your goal for the site


• Tips and tricks to drive traffic and make sales


• How to handle customer service and shipping


• How to create beautiful product images and keyword-rich copy

Panelists

• Ray Hallare, Co-Founder at Dowel Furniture

Dowel makes high quality home furniture that you can customize. They are vertically integrated, which means they can provide you quality pieces at a fraction of what high end furniture would normally cost.

• Michelle Wax, Founder at Boston & Bale & Kitchen Millie 

Michelle Wax is the founder of Kitchen Millie, a two-bite cookie company, and the founder of Boston & Bale, a monthly subscription service that makes discovering local products easy. Both of her companies started out as side hustles and have grown into full time jobs. Michelle is a winner of BetaBoston's 25 Most Innovative People under 25 award and would love to connect with anyone who is interested in bouncing ideas around!

• Deborah Suchman, Co-Founder at Polkadog Bakery 

In 2002, Polkadog Bakery started with a small corner shop in Boston’s South End where we made all of our own dog treats on site.  We have since expanded to four Polkadog retail locations and an industrial kitchen in South Boston where we operate our wholesale. Polkadog treats are now found in independent shops all of over the USA, Canada, and Japan.

Schedule

6- 6:30: Mingle

6:30-7:30: Discussion and Q&A

7:30-End: Mingle

Sponsors

THANK YOU to WeWork for hosting our event!

results.description:
We're very excited for the 2nd New Relic User Group in Boston! Join us for an evening of presentations, collaboration, and Q&A amongst other New Relic users and experts. Food and beverages will be provided.

Check out the schedule & speakers below and RSVP now! Hope to see you there.

Please RSVP on Eventbrite

Schedule 

6:00 - 6:30 Food, Drinks, & Networking 

6:30 - 6:50 David Alves, GQ Partners

6:50 - 7:10 Don Darwin, New Relic

7:10 - 7:30 Ricardo DeMatos, Amazon Web Services

7:30 - 7:50 Tori Wieldt, New Relic - From Pets to Cattle to Bacteria

7:50 - 8:30 Q&A, Discussion 

All New Relic users and fans are welcome! For more New Relic events in Boston, be sure to check out our page on Meetup and keep an eye on the hashtag #NRUG.

Please RSVP on Eventbrite

Talk Details


David Alves, GQ Partners

Pre-Production Performance Budgets based upon Production Metrics

Organizations that care about Customer Experience enforce Pre-Production Performance Budgets.  Performance Budgets are metrics which limit such things as page size, load time, and any other factor that can impact the users experience.  The goal is to either maintain, or better yet, constantly improve your existing Production performance with every release.  In this short presentation, using New Relic Synthetics, our business partners at Global Quality Partners, LLC will show you how you can set and enforce Pre-Production Performance Budgets based upon Performance in Production, as part of your normal Continuous Delivery Lifecycle.

Don Darwin, New Relic

Put Synthetics to Work for You

Learn to use New Relic Synthetics in your testing and production environments to ensure critical processes on your site are available 24x7. Want to use NR Synthetics to monitor your internal sites? Want to learn how to monitor specific assets of your site over a period of time? Come find out how! 

Ricardo DeMatos, Solutions Architect, Amazon Web Services

Run Scalable Application Backends on AWS

Amazon API Gateway is a fully managed service that makes it easy for developers to create, deploy, secure and monitor APIs at any scale. In this session, you’ll find out how you can quickly declare an API interface and connect it to any public HTTP endpoint, existing web service running on Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) or code running on AWS Lambda. Amazon API Gateway handles all the tasks involved in accepting and processing up to hundreds of thousands of concurrent API calls, including traffic management, authorization and access control, monitoring, and API version management. Join us for this introductory session to Amazon API Gateway.

Tori Wieldt, Developer Advocate, New Relic

From Pets to Cattle to Bacteria  

We see a move of servers move from virtualization (cattle) to process separators (bacteria). What will the impact be to have servers that last only last as long a single process? At New Relic, we have customers monitoring Docker containers that last 5 minutes or less. How can organizations plan, develop and operate software in this environment? I’ll provide insights we gathered from our customers and from our own internal use of containers and short-lived servers.

FAQs

What's the closest parking, and how much is it? 

Standard Parking - 1 Broadway Cambridge, MA 02142  

1 Hour $10.00 

2 Hours $15.00 

4 Hours $20.00 

24 Hours $30.00

Yes, right in front of the building.

Transit stops nearby?

The closest Subway stop is at Kendall, Square on the red line which is a 5 minute walk to our offices.

Is the venue wheelchair accessible?

Yes

Where can I contact the organizer with any questions?

If you have any questions, please contact [masked].

results.description:
Join us on Wednesday, September 23 as Mark Chodnowsky from Alstrom (GE) discusses the ethical implications of new technology in intelligence work. A wide range of tools are becoming (or will become) accessible to CI analysts in the next decade, and those tools will provide unprecedented data collection and analysis capability.  In addition, changing individual and societal expectations will influence legal and ethical boundaries.  Businesses and the CI community must be vigilant so that these new technologies are used effectively, yet within the evolving legal and ethical boundaries.  Mark will highlight some of these new tools, issues, and challenges. 


Mark Chodnowsky is currently leading the CI program at Alstom Power. Previously he was SVP at Fuld & Co. where he led three practice areas – IT, Manufacturing, and Consumer Goods. As a consultant for nearly 25 years, he has conducted and managed over 500 research projects and 50 war game exercises for numerous leading multinational corporations. Mark has pioneered several analytical frameworks including competitor strategy mapping and was the originator of the B-School war game championships. He has a BE from Stevens Institute of Technology and an MBA from Carnegie Mellon University.

This Month's Meetup is hosted by:

This month's meetup is sponsored by:

We are still looking for a sponsor for snacks and drinks! If you or your company would like to help out, you earn a spot for your logo on the meetup page for the event, and a shout-out during the meetup (or a chance to talk up your company if you come to the meetup). Please let me know if you are interested in sponsorship.
results.name: Emerging Technologies that Test Ethical Boundaries

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...
results.why: ASL is the third largest "foreign language" in the U.S.; ASL is fun to use; ASL is NOT English, but does "borrow" from the English language.

results.description:
Boston Social Tennis League adds new locations for fall season  

The Boston Social Tennis League will be starting its fall season on Wednesday, September 23 and Thursday, September 24 with two new locations. Due to its rapid growth throughout the spring and summer seasons, additional locations will be added to both league nights. Wednesday nights will now offer league play at Waldstein Playground in Brookline (3 courts, up to 6 teams) and Raiders Field Athletic Complex in West Roxbury (2 courts, up to 4 teams). Thursday night matches will be played at Waldstein Playground and Ringer Park in Allston (2 courts, up to 4 teams). Matches will be played between 6-9 pm and after, players will be invited to enjoy food and drink specials at a nearby bar. Players are more than welcome to sign up for both nights, but not multiple locations on the same night. 

The league will be doubles team play and will run for seven weeks through November 4 and 5. The fee for the league is $60 for new players and includes a USTA New England team t-shirt, weekly bar specials, prizes for the winners and an end-of-the-season party with free food and drinks.  

If you’re interested in joining the fun, register here and follow these steps:

1. Enter the “team number” for the night you want to play and then click enter:

Wednesday night in West Roxbury –[masked]

Wednesday night at Waldstein Playground, Brookline -[masked]

Thursday night at Ringer Playground, Allston -[masked]

Thursday night at Waldstein Playground, Brookline -[masked]

2. Enter your team tennis ID number or membership number 

3. Proceed to checkout and pay the registration fee

Email Christo Schultz at [masked] with questions or a request to be on a certain team. 

To clarify - you don't need to join with a partner.  Anyone can sign up individually, then we'll place you on a team that competes against other teams at your location.

If you're looking for more information on the format of the league, please click here, or contact me (Email above) for any clarifying questions that you might have.  

Looking forward to a great fall season!

results.description:
Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:30pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Mel Choyce is a design engineer at Automattic, where she works mostly on design and front-end development. Feel free to ask her about UI design, UX and user testing, HTML/CSS, and any beginner WordPress questions.

Kelly Dwan is a WordPress developer and core contributor. Familiar with the ins and outs of WordPress, she's happy to answer any theme or plugin development questions, or anything PHP, JS, CSS, HTML.

Paige Eaton is a librarian turned Drupal developer. She loves sports, games, and long walks on the beach, but not too long. It's really tiring to walk on sand. Paige is helpful for questions about UX, HTML, CSS, some PHP, and is a good listener/sounding board for ideas & projects.

Kelly Buchanan is a full stack web dev at an ed tech company. Her background includes web dev, educational research, and computational data analysis. Ask her questions about Python, Ruby, Java, and JavaScript.


Jessica Pang is an interactive designer at ExtensionEngine, a web/mobile app development company. She has spent the past 3 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.


Radhika Malik is a full stack web developer at Panorama Education, an edtech company. Her recent experience has been with HTML, CSS, Javascript and Ruby but she comes from a broad CS background and is happy to work with you to crack any coding problem you might be stuck in!

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Fancy, schmancy (i.e., comfy) Aeron chairs

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)

Location

14th floor, Room Charles

Cambridge Innovation Center

1 Broadway

Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT

Street parking is available on Broadway St., Third St., and Main St.

Access

Please bring photo ID. Upon entering 1 Broadway you'll check in with security. Tell them you're visiting the 14th floor.

Doors open at 6:15pm; if you arrive before 6:15pm, please wait in the 1st floor lobby, as no one will be available to let you in upstairs.

Once you depart the elevator, you'll find glass doors that are locked. Look for the tablet door sign and find your name in the list to ring the doorbell.

We're meeting in the room labeled Charles.

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford

results.description:
Get in shape before the season!! The leader (Bob Barnes) of the Wedeln Ski and Snowboard Race Team will hold dryland training every Wednesday night this Fall. The workout is great for anyone who wants to get in shape, you do not have to be a skier or racer. Bob's enthusiasm for skiing and training is contagious, he will get you working hard and getting results. All fitness levels are welcome but come ready to sweat. Bob will lead the group in Plyometric based training methods designed to get the leg muscles ready for the season. This is the same workout that he has used for many years to prepare for the ski season.

There is no charge - we are just a bunch of skiers and riders trying to help each other get in shape. Darlene Stokes and Tom Lane will also lead the group in additional exercises designed to increase flexibility and build a strong core. Last year we had many people from Meetup join us for these workouts. Some even became regular guests up at our ski house in NH. Ski Fitness Training is a great way to get ready for the season and make some friends you can join on the slopes when the weather gets colder. The workouts last 1.5 hours and are always immediately followed by a few drinks and sometimes some food at a variety of Waltham Center Bars/Restaurants. Please wear work-out clothes and athletic shoes with some ankle support.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the center of Waltham common near the flag poles.
results.name: Pre-season ski fitness training

results.description: The first meet-up was a success! Who's game for a hump day pick-me-up?! I'll do another HIIT session. Since it's mid-workweek it will be a quick 20 minute workout with a few minutes of meditation after. Bring weights and a towel/yoga mat to lay down on.
results.name: Second Time Around!

results.description:
We are back on track!

This is an introductory session to SQL Server Integration Services. 

The intent is  to help you get started with SSIS and perform basic Data Warehouse  ETL tasks.

We will take a look at the core functionality, IDE and Architecture of Integration Services.

You will learn how to create and setup control flow tasks, data-flow components and deploy packages to the Integration Services.

Here is what we are going to do:

• create ssis packages to perform ETL tasks

• extract sensor data from the IoT device (controller);

• load staging tables and data warehouse;

• deploy packages;


Note:  data warehouse design out of scope, but i will go over the basics.

Also we will leverage DDD (Domain Driven Development) methodology to build data warehouse while building the ETL (SSIS packages). 

You can bring you laptop to follow along. Don't forget to download the files:  http://files.meetup.com/10128932/apex_controller.zip

Level: 100


Tools:


Sql Server 2012 and above. I will be using Sql Server 2016 CTP 2.3

Sql Server Database Tools BI Edition for Visual Studio 2013 (FREE download).

Speaker: 

Slava Kokaev Lead Business Intelligence Architect at Lockheed Martin , Mentor, INETA Regional Speaker and Boston Microsoft Business Intelligence User Group Leader specializing in Business Intelligence Systems, Data Analytics and  Security Intelligence.

Pizza and Soda (Free) provided by Pragmatic Works

Parking: There is free <a>MIT parking lot on Hayward Street</a>.  There is also a free lot across from the Alewife T stop at the <a>Summer Shack</a>. 

Note: 

6:20 PM ~ 6:45 PM Pizza and Networking time.

6:45 PM ~ 8:45 PM Main Session
results.name: Integration Services Workshop (FREE)

results.description:
September's Meetup is all about the future of ops through Ansible and we're assembling an expert team to present and answer your questions.

Brian Coca, Senior Software Engineer at Ansible, will be taking the train up to Boston to discuss what the future has in store for Ansible 2.0.

Bret Swedeen, Senior Cloud Solution Architect at G2 Technology Group, will be talking about Patch Management through Ansible.

We’ll be closing out the evening with a round of Open Spaces. Everyone in attendance will have their chance to suggest a topic for breakout group discussion and debate.

Thanks to our host-sponsor Bob Calise from YEC.co for the hook-up at WeWork.

Due to security at WeWork, all attendees will be required to check-in for the Meetup at the security desk. However, if you register for the event by 9/21, you will get to go through express check-in.

Thank you to Sonos for sponsoring the food for the Meetup, we'll be ordering pizza from Uppercrust for everyone! And thank you to DataRobot for sponsoring drinks for the evening!
results.name: Ansible Boston Meetup - The Future of Ops through Ansible

results.description:
More Great Speeches: Wed, Sep 23.

Did you ever imagine speaking could be fun?

Our last Meet-ups won rave reviews from first-time guests. They enjoyed the simple exercises and learned useful techniques for connecting with an audience.

Our meet-ups are fast-paced and entertaining. Nobody feels intimidated. Come experience it for yourself: You'll get to listen to prepared speeches and learn simple yet effective speaking tips.


You are welcome to participate in our two-minute impromptu speaking exercises, but certainly not required. We do have a 30-second “Round Robin” that everyone participates in (it’s fun and easy), and you’ll probably be asked to introduce yourself [talk very briefly about an interest, or what brought you there]. Pretty basic, no surprises.  The only requirement is to enjoy yourself and get a sense of how the meet-ups run. [They start promptly at 6:50, so please arrive by or before 6:45. They end by 8:30 pm.]


Mark Your Calendar - Our Next Meet-Ups:

Wed, Sept 23, (6:45 PM)

3rd Floor, Room 103. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.

Parking: If you can't find street parking (free after 6 PM), There is parking to the rear of the bldg. You will present ticket to the security desk on your way out ($3), then insert the ticket at the gate as you exit.
(Don't park in the supermarket/Porter Square shopping center parking lot.)


See the "About Us" tab for more info.
results.how_to_find_us: 3rd Floor, Room 103. You must take the elevator by the security desk to access the floor.
results.name: Sparkle When You Speak Wed Sep 23, Build confidence

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

Welcome Back Party for All Nurses & Nursing Students (21+) for a huge rocking party at the Good Life Boston - voted the Best Bar and Dance Club in the City!

results.description:
On the fourth Wednesday of each month, BACA hosts an evening of Open Mic Cabaret. Cabaret, jazz, torch songs and show tunes are typical for these evenings, but other reasonable genres include pop, soul, folk, soft rock, ballads, etc.

If you want to belt out a song or two, or just come to watch and support all levels of performers, please join us at this very friendly and fun evening.

Admission is $10/$13/$7 (members/singers/audience).     Where else in Boston can you get so much entertainment for such a low price? *You may want to inquire about BACA's $40 annual membership for cost savings on events as well as other wonderful benefits!.

Sign-ups to sing and the show begins at 7pm (the earlier you arrive, the more of a chance you can sing two songs!). Also, in order to sing, you will need to bring sheet music so the pianist can accompany you, optimally in your key.

The Venue:

Two blocks from Watertown Square. Mass Pike Exit 17, go north on Centre/Galen St, left on Main St, right on Church St. By public transit, many buses go there, including #71 from Harvard Square. Many restaurants within easy walk. FREE parking available in the bank lot adjacent to the church off Summer St., additional free parking on Summer St. If no lot or street parking available, there is a large municipal parking lot one block away between Church and Spring Streets behind the CVS and Stellina's restaurant. Church has Steinway Model B grand piano and concert acoustics. FYI the church's web site: http://fpwatertown.org Google Map and Directions: http://goo.gl/maps/8MBJp Accompanist: TBA

Please come by, say hello, and enjoy the show!

Cheers,

-Matt
results.how_to_find_us: Walk In from Church Street. Please enter through main (front) door.
results.name: BACA Open Mic at Watertown Square

results.description:
Wild animals are natural herbalists. From bears to panthers to deer, they have been observed selectively foraging for medicinal plants when ill or injured, able to recognize the appropriate medicines by instinct. Domestic animals, too, retain this affinity for herbal medicine, and respond well to the use of herbs for their own ailments.
Come learn safe, simple, and effective herbal and nutritional therapies for your dogs, cats, or other companion animals. We’ll discuss the use of herbs for behavioral problems, infestations (fleas, ticks, worms, etc), minor injuries, and common illnesses. Methods of preparation and administration will also be covered.

Join us for this class, and learn to give your furry friends a little love and care in a language their bodies innately understand!

Wednesday, September 23rd, 2015
7:00 – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.
RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Herbs for Pets

results.description:
"Liberalism and (not vs.) Conservatism" as relates to everything. The idea of liberality (moving forward) and conservativism (preserving the good or right) can be related to so many things: social, political, religious, ideological, etc... it is almost de facto in our (Somerville) culture that we side with liberality, but I wonder at what cost. When is a conservative approach more appropriate, even at the expense of an openness to the new or improved. On the other hand, in what areas are we too conservative and need to become open or liberal. A Mark Twain quote as food for thought:
"The radical of one century is the conservative of the next. The radical invents the views. When he has worn them out the conservative adopts them."
results.name: Liberalism and Conservatism

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we meet to discuss Chapters 21 & 22 of Keynes' "General Theory", as well as Chapters 21 & 22 of Hazlitt's line-by-line critique of "Failure of the New Economics." The readings are not required to attend our meeting, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

READINGS:

"The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money"
by J.M. Keynes
Chapters 21 & 22
http://bit.ly/1QDOIeY

"The Failure of the New Economics"
by Henry Hazlitt
Chapters 21 & 22
http://bit.ly/1RKJIZk

QUESTIONS:

1) According to Keynes, how does stationary equilibrium differ from shifting equilibrium?

2) According to Keynes, the general price-level depends on which factor?

3) According to Keynes, the ratio between the quantity of effective demand and the quantity of money corresponds to which phenomenon?

4) According to Keynes, the “crisis” refers to which phenomenon, and how is this theory counteracted?

5) According to Keynes, a boom is characterized by which phenomenon?

6) According to Hazlitt, when do prices determine cost, regarding price formation?

7) According to Hazlitt, the “Quantity Theory of Money” makes which assumption, disputed by Hazlitt?

8) According to Hazlitt, the elasticity of demand and the elasticity of supply are alike in which way?

9) According to Hazlitt, what is Keynes' critique of the free-market?

10) According to Hazlitt, what contributes to the rise in commodity pricing?
results.name: PRICE THEORY AND THE TRADE CYCLE

We get together at Paneras Bread to speak Spanish every other Wednesday. Please join us for some very informal conversation.

To help cover the cost of using Meetup.com, a voluntary $3-4 donation per meeting is always appreciated. (Pero es GRATIS para hablantes nativos! ).
results.how_to_find_us: Look for us in the back of the restaurant.  Sometimes new people have missed us. So, don't be shy.
results.name: SS Spanish Meetup @ Panera's in Braintree

results.description:
We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.

Our group has been running since 2007, and at this point we have a pretty large crowd of regulars.  A lot of people come once every few weeks, and RSVPs are appreciated but not required, so the RSVP list is often smaller than our actual attendance.  We expect about 35-55 people at most of our meetups.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
Meeting the 2nd and 4th Wednesday of every month, this class works from the “Astrology for Yourself” Workbook and it is recommended that you have this available.

"The Art of Chart Interpretation"


Over the Spring 2015 and into the Summer we will be going over the art of reading a chart. Not just the meaning of a planet in a sign or house but the dynamic of the chart and what it tells us about the native. We will look at our psychological makeup and how to see what really stands out in a chart. How to move with the patterns in a birth chart and learn from them not be ruled by them.

This group is for people with some basic Astrology knowledge and is learning at a beginner/advanced beginner level. Please bring your birth chart if you have one, or give your birth information when you register.

This class sets its own agenda dealing with current events, current planetary placement such as lunar cycles or retrograde planets. Discussions are centered on these factors and how they impact us on a more personal level as individuals.

Come on by and join the fun!

If you need a fresh chart or don't have one and you plan to come please contact me, Dorothy at [masked] with your birth information and I will happily bring one to the meeting.

Namaste'

results.description:
Do you believe that we are Made of Energy and not Matter? For some this is not actually new, while for others it is hard to believe. This theory dates back to the times of Plato & Socrates who posited that energy, or soul, is separate from matter, and that the universe is made of energy – pure energy which was there before man and other material things like the earth came along.


Then by the end of the seventeenth century Newtonian physics became the corner-stone of science, and it was based on the theory that there is only matter and nothing else – the whole universe is a machine, made of matter, and so are we.


Today, Medical science is still stuck in the Newtonian concept, even though the rest of science has now moved on to quantum physics.

Quantum physics says that as you go deeper and deeper into the workings of the atom, you see that there is nothing there – just energy waves. It says an atom is actually an invisible force field, a kind of miniature tornado, which emits waves of electrical energy.

Energy is all around you. The more people become aware of it, the more you feel it, and the more conscious the planet is becomes.  Energy flows through your body and it is vital to understand this knowledge in order to heal yourself.


This workshop is about energy - how it flows through your body and everything around you, and how you can use it to create health in yourself and in others.

• Learn about Energy from a scientific stand point.

• You will experience the feeling of energy and utilizing it for change.

• You will learn techniques to ground yourself with the flow of energy of nature.

• You will learn to resolve pain with Energy from God and the universe.

Receive ideas and good words on how to energetically combat a common cold or bacterial infections that have always been successful for Christy.

Christy Matoon began her Spiritual Journey back in 2012 after she made the decision to take back her health. It was then that she hired a personal trainer,  released 300 lbs, and became a NASM-Certified Personal Trainer, Corrective Exercise Specialist, Fitness Nutrition SpecialistTRX® Level 2 Trainer – Straps, Sticks, and Sports MedicineCrossfit, Level 1 Certified Trainer. In February of 2015, Christy became a PSYCH-K® (Basic, Advanced, Pro) Facilitator. She also is a Neurokinetic Therapy® Certified Practitioner, Associative Awareness Techniques™Splankna Practitioner and Spiritual Coach. For more info about Christy go to www.Buildingchangenow.com

This is a fun class and is sure to fill up quickly.

results.name: Christy Mattoon - The Energy Flow Workshop!

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11
results.how_to_find_us: The third table in the middle of the climbing area between 7:00-7:10 PM. It's the table in the middle of the TR \/ Lead area.
results.name: Brooklyn Boulders Somerville Wednesday

results.description:
Have you ever heard of race amity? No? It’s an under acknowledged American tradition of cooperation and love that unfolded in parallel to racial oppression. Race amity and racial oppression are as opposite as yin and yang, yet both have had profound effects on society. Come explore race amity at the September World Citizens’ Café! Dr. William Smith, founding executive director of the National Center for Race Amity at Wheelock College, will lead us on an exploration of race amity’s history and influence. Come prepared for an eye-opening talk and thought- provoking conversation as well as the comedy of former Cambridge resident Robert Shapiro, music and time to nibble and schmooze! The Café is free of charge and open to all. Light refreshments will be served.

We encourage you to bring a story, artifact, poem, photograph or anything relevant that you would like to share. And, bring a friend!

Are you a Facebook fan? Visit us at
www.facebook.com/groups/WCCFramingham/

Questions? Contact Phil Cantor [masked]; [masked]

The World Citizens' Cafe thanks the Amazing Things Arts Center in Framingham for its ongoing support (www.amazingthings.org)
results.name: Let's Meet Up and Explore Race Amity: America's Forgotten Traditon

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
